Vi har jo ved flere andre lejligheder vist, hvad vi kan tilsammen i det her land.  Nu skal vi i de kommende uger få banket smitten så meget ned, som det overhovedet kan lade sig gøre.  Det var mine indledende ord, så giver jeg i første omgang ordet videre til sundhedsministeren.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech at press conference on additional coronar restrictions
speeches_EN: Welcome to just five days into the new year, we stand here again, unfortunately. A new and disturbing development in the pandemic has hit us: the British mutation of the coronavirus, which is a particularly contagious version. The consistents of the UK are already violent, where the mutation is now very widespread. But it also spreads in Denmark and large parts of Europe and the United States. In these hours and days, countries have to deal with what to do in a new situation. We have now gone to level 5 in the warning system, ie the highest level. This means that the authorities estimate that there is widespread community infection and the risk that the treatment capacity in hospitals will be exceeded. In Denmark, we have to sharpen the efforts again. The restrictions we have are not enough. It is the assessment both from our own authorities and from the experts they consult with. Therefore, today we will lower the assembly ban to five people and come up with new initiatives. I elaborate on them in a little while. But we also come up with a very powerful appeal for the time until January 17, ie barely the next two weeks. And that's: Stay as much as possible at home. Work from home if you can. Only buy in one person at a time and only do it when needed. Avoid meeting with people other than those from your household and your very closest. In short: Cancel all the appointments you can, wherever possible. Why is it necessary with this sharpened approach? The new mutation is not considered to be more dangerous in itself, but it is much more contagious. It is the opinion of the health authorities that the consequences of the spread of infection with the new mutation of the virus can be extremely serious. We see it right now in the UK, yesterday alone they had almost 60,000 infected in a day, a month ago the figure was 16,000 infected per month. Day. Also in Denmark, the infection basket will be steeper and have a higher top point compared to the virus we know. And in addition, a right proportion of the population will have to be immune to achieve herd immunity. If we do not succeed in delaying the mutation, then it will cause more hospitalizations, more serious illnesses, more will risk dying, and our healthcare system will come under even greater pressure than it already is. Therefore, we are again in a really serious situation. Just before I used the word delay. And that's because that's what is our job right now. The mutation is already so widespread both at home and in the world that it cannot be stopped. But we can delay and we can pull out the time, so that every day we can vaccinate even more. The health authorities have stated that on Friday, January 8, it is expected that all nursing home residents who wish to be vaccinated, which will receive the first dose of the vaccine. It's really, really happy news, but there is still a long way to go. Denmark is currently the country in the EU that has vaccinated the largest proportion of its population. It's really well done. In several places, healthcare professionals have succeeded in getting even more doses out of the first delivery of vaccines. And fortunately we also receive a little more vaccines than expected. The government's attitude, it is completely clear: The moment the vaccines hit Danish soil, they have to work out. And we are working on even more people being used right away. We have set the goal that we should be able to vaccinate 100,000 Danes a day when we have the vaccines for it. Until we are enough long with the vaccines, we must keep the infection down. A task that now with the British mutation has unfortunately become even more difficult. The effort, it rests in three areas. First of course, we must of course avoid more infection to Denmark. This is especially true of the British variant, but also other mutations that may occur. There are already stricter entry restrictions for foreigners living in the UK, as a predominant starting point they are rejected entry to Denmark, and everyone who wants to fly from there and to Denmark must now show a negative test before they are allowed to board the aircraft. Like all travel - this also applies to business trips - to our English neighbors are advised. The government is considering today with the authorities whether in the coming days there is a need for further restrictions on entry from other countries. And whether we should further tighten our guidance on traveling out into the world. We expect Soon to announce in relation to the mutation found in South Africa. Secondly, we have to find and we have to break infection chains. Although Denmark is one of the countries that tests most in our size, we need to go even further. The capacity it needs to be used and it must be used every day. There are too few who are being tested in the days we are in now. The government has therefore decided that the authorities must ensure as soon as possible that staff at care centers in all regions can be quickly tested, and models must also be developed for testing staff in, for example, day care institutions. On top of tests that come then the infection tracking. It has been continuously expanded, but it needs to go up in gear again. Therefore, the government has again made it clear to the authorities that the resources that are needed we make them available. In addition to what everyone knows, namely with tests and detection, something new has come to, namely sequencing. And that is, study of the positive tests that are made so that it can be identified whether the people who get sick by Corona in Denmark will be of the English mutation, and in the future may also be a further mutation. Denmark is already one of the countries that sequenced the most, that's good. But the ambition must be right up. And that is why the goal is that we can sequence all positive tests in Denmark. Therefore, the authorities will also involve all relevant partners in the coming days, and this is also an invitation to the private business for increased cooperation in this area. Thirdly, there are the restrictions and our behavior each. As of tomorrow, January 6, lowering the assembly ban, as we know it, from 10 people to five people. This happens after discussion with the party leaders in Christiansborg earlier today. Similarly, the authorities' recommendation is changed so that everyone is encouraged to limit social contact to a maximum of five people, nor do more than five people meet in private homes. Of course, if you live more than that in the household, it is not covered, just as a permanent partner and children are not. In addition, there are a number of exceptions to the assembly ban, which will either be removed or adjusted over the coming hours and today. On the whole, until January 17, it is a strong appeal to cancel all appointments you and you can cancel. And therefore also an important message: Because the new variant infects much more, the health authorities now also change the recommendations of what is known as the distance requirement. We have to keep two meters away between each other again. This applies in the grocery stores when we buy groceries, but it also applies in the public space when we meet each other on the path in the forest. The assembly ban is one of the most intrusive during this pandemic, therefore the reduction to five people is currently only valid until 17 January. It is the same date when the other stricter restrictions are set to expire. In this context, I would like to say that it is unfortunately our expectation that it may be necessary to extend all or part of the stricter restrictions. You have to put your mind after that. As for the day care institutions, it is still the health authorities' assessment that it is justifiable to keep them open. At the same time, I would like to emphasize, so many people need to get their children cared for. It is pleased in Production Denmark, it applies to those who work out in the grocery stores, the health care system, the elderly area, the disability area and several other places. And as a country we need, even though we are again a critical place that as many people as possible go to work. Whether at the screen at home or by physical attendance. The fact that we can maintain the most economic activity is crucial for our society not to stop or even backwards. But it is clear, also in this area, which is an ongoing assessment of whether the effort is sufficient. The reality is now here at the entrance of the new year that there are few opportunities to shut down even more, and therefore our efforts are becoming more important. Of course, as I have said so, many press meetings, the government does not want to keep Denmark closed one day more than what it is needed. By doing more now, we also increase the likelihood that we can get started with a proper reopening, but it is not right now, unfortunately. Until then, it is the government's call for companies to maintain the level of activity and organize the work. with homework and the initiatives that have already been tested in many places. In my New Year's speech a few days ago, I said that January and February can be the worst months in the pandemic. This was the case with the coronavirus we already know, now we have to put the British, aggressive variant of virus on top. And we are currently in a real race over time. In the next few months, the hardest ones will be, then we go towards spring, where viruses fortunately get more difficult conditions again. And we are also going into a time when more and more people will be vaccinated. After all, we have shown on several other occasions what we can together in this country. Now in the coming weeks we will have to knock down the infection as much as it can at all. These were my initial words, then I initially pass the word on to the Minister of Health.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens nytårstale
speeches_dk: God aften. Vi har taget hul på et nyt år. Og det kan kun blive bedre end det gamle. 2020 var et hårdt år. Et usikkert år. Pandemiens år. Men det var også et fælles år på en måde, vi sjældent oplever. På tværs af generationer. På tværs af landet. På tværs af de forskellige mennesker, vi nu engang er – har vi stået med hinandens liv i vores hænder. Det har vi ganske enkelt aldrig prøvet før. Nye ord er kommet til. Kontakttal. Smittetryk. Værnemidler. Vi har fumlet med mundbind og stået i kø til test. Vi har opdaget, hvor meget børn kan savne deres skole. Og vi blev mindet om, hvad det betyder at have et arbejde. Vi har åbnet vinduet mod en mennesketom gade og set op på en himmel, der var klart blå uden en eneste flystribe. Vi har set verden i slowmotion. Mens sygdommen hærgede, fandt den sidste turist hjem, den sidste fest blev aflyst, og alt blev så stille, at vi kunne høre hjertets slag. Vi oplevede menneskets ældgamle sårbarhed og fandt en ny styrke. Når tilværelsen skæres ind til kernen – liv og død – bliver det hele på en gang mere kompliceret og mere enkelt. Vi vil fortælle om tiden under pandemien fra generation til generation. Ligesom mange af os selv blev fortalt om livet under Anden Verdenskrig. Det, vi gennemlever i denne tid, er historisk. * * * Vi står sammen ved at holde afstand. Alligevel er vi kommet tættere på hinanden. Overalt i samfundet har vi oplevet sammenhold, hjælpsomhed og rørende øjeblikke i et omfang, vi ikke har set i Danmark før. I hvert fald ikke i min levetid. Ingen er kommet igennem krisen uden fællesskabet. Om det er hjælpepakkerne til erhvervslivet. Kollegaen, der har taget endnu en ekstra vagt. De forlængede dagpenge. Naboen, der har handlet ind. Alle har ofret noget. Alle har ydet deres. Vi er i samme båd. Vi har måttet sætte hensynet til hinanden først. Hver især. Nogle synes, at den pris er høj. Det forstår jeg godt. Men alternativet var værre. Det er det stadigvæk. I en tid, hvor det ellers er nemt at splitte. Har vi meget overbevisende valgt sammenholdet. 2020 skriver sig ind i historien som et år, der har haft mange helte. På en helt særlig måde. For vores heltedåd under pandemien er også det, vi ikke gjorde. At vi ikke gav hånd. At vi udskød en fest. Den måde at være ”helt” på ligger nok godt til os danskere. Vi er ikke til store armbevægelser. Men vi forstår at tage ansvar og passe på hinanden. Med alle de små handlinger, som summer op til den store bedrift. Derfor kan jeg i aften sige det, som det var og er: Du, der ser med i aften – du har reddet menneskeliv! Så enkelt er det. Og så enestående. Du ved ikke selv, hvem du har reddet. Det kan være en kvinde, du gik forbi på gaden, og som lider af en kronisk sygdom. Du har ved din adfærd brudt smittekæden, så sygdommen ikke ramte hende. Jeg ved godt, at det ikke er nogen trøst for jer, der i aften sidder tilbage med savnet af én, I har mistet. En mor eller far. En ægtefælle. En bror eller søster. En søn eller datter. En god ven. Hver mistet liv er et tab. En historie, der slutter. Og må bæres videre i minderne. Jeg tror på, at vi i dag har lagt det værste år bag os. Men vi må forvente, at de sværeste måneder er foran os. Januar og februar vil teste vores udholdenhed. Årstiden er imod os. Flere vil blive syge. Presset på sygehusene er allerede stort. Endnu større på det personale, vi i forvejen skylder så uendeligt meget. Situationen er alvorlig. Derfor har vi forlænget nedlukningen af store dele af samfundet indtil midt i januar. Men uanset hvilke restriktioner der indføres med begrænsninger og nedlukninger – uanset hvor mange der testes – så er der en ting, der er vigtigere end noget andet: vores indsats hver især. Vi ved, hvad der virker. Når vi bliver utålmodige – og det bliver vi – så håber jeg, vi husker. At mørket er tættest, lige før solen bryder frem. Vi kan allerede skimte daggryet forude. Over hele kloden blev 2020 det år, hvor menneskers største udfordring pludselig var den samme. De erfaringer, vi har gjort os. De drømme, vi har haft. Var mere ens end ellers på tværs af landegrænser og kontinenter. Nu knytter vi et fælles håb til vaccinerne. Det er imponerende, hvad verden kan, når alle arbejder sammen. Længe leve forskningen og samarbejdet mellem det offentlige og det private. Længe leve videnskaben. Vaccinen er vores vej tilbage til hverdagen. Samværet. Krammet. Festerne. Alt det, vi længes efter. Men vaccinen er ikke en smutvej til at ophæve restriktionerne. Eller slække på adfærden. Ikke endnu. Vinteren bliver hård. Men for hver uge, der går, vil stadig flere danskere være vaccinerede. Påskedag er i år den 4. april. Her vil årstiden igen hjælpe os. Vi vil være nået langt med vaccinationerne. Jeg tror – jeg håber – at påsken bliver vores vendepunkt. Ikke en afslutning. Men et vendepunkt. Indtil da må vi holde fast i alt det, vi kan sammen. Danmark er et pragmatisk land. Vi finder fælles løsninger. Hele 14 trepartsaftaler er det blevet til med fagforeninger og arbejdsgivere. Virksomheder har omlagt produktion for at lave håndsprit. Offentligt ansatte har løst problemerne under svære vilkår. Det private og offentlige har tilsammen vist innovation og kreativitet på imponerende vis. Der er så uendeligt mange at sige tak til. Folketinget og folkevalgte i både kommuner og regioner har lagt hverdagens uenigheder til side og arbejdet for det fælles bedste. Selvfølgelig har der også været diskussioner. Og kritik. Det skal der være. Men som Hal Koch så rigtigt sagde det allerede i 1945. Demokrati er meget mere end en styreform. Det er en livsform. Det er ikke afstemningerne, der er demokratiets egentlige styrke. Det er samtalen. Og viljen til at finde fælles løsninger. Vi har grund til at glæde os over, hvor stærkt og levende et demokrati vi har. Aftaler og samarbejde har skabt resultater i et hidtil uset omfang. I alle dele af vores samfund. Vi har bevist meget i 2020. Sidst på foråret var de økonomiske udsigter dystre. Med en forventning om, at den samlede økonomiske aktivitet ville falde med mere end fem procent i løbet af året. Vi forhindrede, at det gik så galt. Vi viste, at sundhed og økonomi hænger tæt sammen. Fordi det at begrænse smitten er helt afgørende for trygheden. Og dermed for, at der kommer gang i forbruget og økonomien igen. Det så vi hen over sommeren, hvor vi havde nogle måneder med betydelig økonomisk fremgang. Godt hjulpet af hjælpepakker og andre tiltag, der holdt hånden under købekraften. Dansk økonomi har klaret sig bedre gennem det sidste år, end vi først havde frygtet. Ligesom arbejdsløsheden er steget mindre end forventet. Mere end halvdelen af de job i Danmark, som gik tabt i foråret, var vundet tilbage i sensommeren. Men som det ofte sker, har krisen ramt de ufaglærte hårdest. Vi vil gøre alt, hvad vi kan, for at I også kommer tilbage i arbejde. Måske kræver det, at du efteruddanner dig. Selvom du ikke har de bedste minder fra skoletiden. Så er min opfordring alligevel: Gør det. Det kan være din vej ud af krisen. * * * Pandemien har været et forstørrelsesglas på vores samfund. På Danmark. Vi har set svaghederne. Men vi har først og fremmest vist styrkerne ved vores samfundsmodel. Overbevisende. At vi har klaret den indtil nu, er ikke tilfældigt. Det skyldes de valg, vi traf sammen. Det er mit ønske for fremtiden, at alt hvad vi har udrettet, vil inspirere os. Jeg tror mere end nogensinde på, at vi i fællesskab kan klare de udfordringer, vi som samfund har foran os. Også de allersværeste. For hvis vi kan bekæmpe en global pandemi. Fordi vi beslutter os for det. Fordi vi står sammen. Så tænk på alt det andet, vi også kan. Det gælder klimaet, miljøet og naturen. Da et bredt flertal i Folketinget satte det mål, at drivhusgasserne skal reduceres med 70 procent i 2030. Havde vi 10 år til at nå målet. Nu er det første år gået. Og på bare ét år har vi allerede truffet beslutninger, der bringer os en tredjedel af vejen. Det er ikke så ringe endda, som man siger der, hvor jeg kommer fra. Vi har besluttet en slutdato for vores olieproduktion. Og med aftaler om både elbiler, en grøn skattereform, havvind fra energiøer, mere affaldssortering, 15 nye naturnationalparker, urørt skov og øget elektrificering er vi godt på vej til at indfri de løfter, vi har givet. Nu skal vi i gang med at omlægge dansk landbrug til endnu mere klimavenlig produktion. Og i takt med at verden åbner igen, vil efterspørgslen på grønne løsninger stige. Det er nu, vi skal kombinere dansk erhvervsliv, forskning og høje klimaambitioner. Den grønne omstilling skal lykkes. Og vi kan lykkes. Danmark skal vise verden, at politik betyder noget. Vi skal stå ved det, vi tror på. Det gælder også i udlændingepolitikken. Som samfund må vi træde mere i karakter. Stå fast på vores danske værdier. Vi må ikke acceptere, at demokratiet lægges for had i parallelsamfund. Radikalisering skal ikke beskyttes. Den skal afsløres. Regeringen vil gentænke integrationsindsatsen, så den i højere grad bygger på tydelige krav og klare forventninger. Med fokus på ret og pligt. Helt grundlæggende må det være sådan, at når man har fået ophold i Danmark, så skal man selvfølgelig forsørge sig selv. Hvis det i en periode ikke kan lade sig gøre, vil regeringen foreslå, at man – til gengæld for sin ydelse – får pligt til at bidrage med, hvad der svarer til en almindelig arbejdsuge på 37 timer. Det er nogle af de opgaver, der står foran os i det nye år. I aften vil jeg også tale mere om et emne, der fylder mindre i den offentlige debat. Sammenhængen på tværs af vores land. Næsten hver anden dansker bor uden for de større byer. Danmark er så lille. At uanset hvor du befinder dig. Så er du aldrig mere end 50 kilometer fra havet. Alligevel er mulighederne blevet mere skævt fordelt. Du kan ikke længere blive lærer i Haslev. Nu skal du til Roskilde eller Vordingborg. Du kan ikke mere gå på erhvervsskole i Maribo. Nu er det nærmeste sted Nakskov eller Nykøbing. I mange byer, der tidligere havde et sygehus, er det blevet lukket. Kalundborg. Faaborg. Haderslev. Dronninglund. Politistationer er nedlagt. Nogle siger, at ”sådan er udviklingen”. Men det er ikke udvikling. Det er mange steder afvikling. Og det kan vi ændre – hvis vi vil. På en måde, hvor vi ikke behøver at skabe falske modsætninger. Jeg er stolt af vores hovedstad. København er en fantastisk by. Resten af verden misunder os havnen, man kan svømme i. Cykelstierne. Kunsten og kulturen. En by, der stadig huser sin egen befolkning, og hvor der også er liv og boliger midt i byen. Vi skal både have en stærk hovedstad. Velfungerende provinsbyer.  Små bysamfund. Og levende landdistrikter. Jylland, Sjælland, Fyn og øerne kan noget andet end hovedstaden. Naturen er tættere på. De mindre samfund oplever ofte et stærkt fællesskab. Måske slår både uret og hjertet lidt roligere. I København har vi brug for flere boliger, der er til at betale. Og mindre støj og forurening fra trafikken. I andre dele af landet er udfordringerne nogle andre. Over de kommende år åbner vi derfor 20 nye nærpolitistationer. Ni i Jylland. Ni på Sjælland. To på Fyn. I det nye år vil vi etablere flere muligheder for, at unge kan uddanne sig lokalt – tæt på, hvor de bor og kommer fra. Vi tager også fat på det problem, at alt for mange danskere ikke har mulighed for at få deres egen praktiserende læge. Det gælder særligt på Lolland-Falster, på Vestsjælland, i Nordjylland og i dele af de større byer – blandt andet nogle boligområder i København. Politi. Uddannelser. Lægedækning. Der skal være velfærd i hele landet. Det handler også om økonomien. Derfor vil regeringen foreslå en egentlig ”velfærdslov”. Den skal – hvis den bliver vedtaget – sikre, at pengene følger med. Når vi heldigvis bliver flere børn og flere ældre. På den måde holder vi hånden under velfærden i hele landet. Nok er tyngdekraften en naturlov. Men det er centraliseringen ikke. * * * For 100 år siden var Danmark og verden også ramt af en pandemi. Det var ”den spanske syge”. En, som levede dengang, har skildret det sådan her: ”Der er Hjem (…), hvor de ligger syge allesammen og ingen har til at hjælpe sig; de maa kravle ud af Sengene og hjælpe hinanden.” ”Plejersker er der ingen af, og Læger knap heller.” Det er forfatteren Martin Andersen Nexø. Han beskriver også, hvordan ”Ligvogne kørte i Galop gennem Gaderne for at overkomme de mange Dødsfald.” Det viser tydeligt forskellen på dengang og i dag. Dengang manglede det Danmark, som vi har nu. Det velfærdssamfund, som generationer før os har bygget. Under pandemien kæmper vi for dem – for dig – der har lagt stenene til det samfund, vi andre nyder godt af. Og som står i forreste række, når sygdommen kræver sine ofre. Hvis nogen tvivlede på, at Danmark fandtes. Som fællesskab. Som land. Så tvivl ikke længere. Min tale i aften er en hyldest til Danmark. Til alle jer, der til sammen udgør vores dejlige land. 2020 er et år, vi aldrig vil glemme. Og ja – januar og februar bliver hårde. Men så kommer foråret. Bøgen springer ud. Fuglene kommer igen. Til sommer de lyse nætter. 2021 bliver bedre. Tak til alle i Danmark for indsatsen. Godt nytår!
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's New Year's speech
speeches_EN: Good evening. We've started a new year. And it can only get better than the old one. 2020 was a tough year. An uncertain year. The year of the pandemic. But it was also a common year in a way we rarely experience. Across generations. Across the country. Across the different people we are now - we have stood with each other's lives in our hands. We have simply never tried that before. New words have come to. Contact numbers. Ingunes. Protective equipment. We have fumbled with mouthwash and queued for testing. We have discovered how much children can miss their school. And we were reminded of what it means to have a job. We have opened the window towards a human street and looked up at a sky that was clearly blue without a single aircraft. We've seen the world in slow motion. While the disease ravaged, the last tourist found home, the last party was canceled and everything became so quiet that we could hear the stroke of the heart. We experienced the ancient vulnerability of man and found a new strength. When life is cut into the core - life and death - it all becomes more complicated and simpler at once. We will tell you about the time during the pandemic from generation to generation. Like many of ourselves were told about life during World War II. What we are experiencing during this time is historic. * * * We stand together by keeping distance. Still, we've come closer to each other. Everywhere in society we have experienced unity, helpfulness and touching moments to an extent we have not seen in Denmark before. At least not in my lifetime. No one has come through the crisis without the community. Whether it is the aid packages for business. The colleague who has taken another extra guard. They extended unemployment benefits. The neighbor who has traded in. Everyone has sacrificed something. Everyone has provided theirs. We are in the same boat. We have had to put the consideration of each other first. Each. Some think that price is high. I understand that. But the alternative was worse. It's still it. In a time when it is otherwise easy to split. We have very convincingly chosen the unity. 2020 writes into history as a year that has had many heroes. In a very special way. For our heroic thigh under the pandemic is also what we did not do. That we did not give hand. That we postponed a party. The way of being "totally" is probably good for us Danes. We are not into big arm movements. But we understand how to take responsibility and take care of each other. With all the little actions that buzz up to the great achievement. Therefore, tonight I can say it as it was and are: You who watch tonight - you have saved human life! So simple is it. And then unique. You don't even know who you've saved. It may be a woman you passed on the street and who is suffering from a chronic illness. You have broken the infection chain in your behavior so that the disease did not hit her. I know it's no comfort for you who are left with the missing of one that you have lost tonight. A mother or father. A spouse. A brother or sister. A son or daughter. A good friend. Every lost life is a loss. A story that ends. And must be carried on in the memories. I believe that today we have put the worst year behind us. But we must expect the most difficult months to be ahead of us. January and February will test our stamina. The season is against us. More will get sick. The pressure in hospitals is already large. Even greater on the staff we already owe so much. The situation is serious. Therefore, we have extended the shutdown of large parts of the community until mid -January. But no matter what restrictions are introduced with restrictions and shutdowns - no matter how many are tested - there is one thing that is more important than anything else: our efforts each. We know what works. When we become impatient - and we will be - then I hope we remember. That darkness is closest, just before the sun breaks out. We can already glimpse dawn ahead. Across the globe, 2020 became the year when people's biggest challenge was suddenly the same. The experiences we have gained. The dreams we have had. Were more similar than otherwise across borders and continents. Now we attach a common hope to the vaccines. It is impressive what the world can do when everyone works together. Long live research and cooperation between the public and the private. Long live science. The vaccine is our way back to everyday life. Togetherness. Hugged. The parties. All that we long for. But the vaccine is not a dirt road to abolish the restrictions. Or slack on the behavior. Not yet. Winter will be tough. But for each week that goes by, more and more Danes will be vaccinated. Easter Day is this year on April 4th. Here the season will help us again. We will have come a long way with the vaccinations. I think - I hope - that Easter will be our turning point. Not an ending. But a turning point. Until then, we have to hold on to everything we can together. Denmark is a pragmatic country. We find common solutions. A total of 14 tripartite agreements have been created with unions and employers. Companies have rescheduled production to make handgun. Public employees have solved the problems under difficult conditions. Together, the private and public have shown innovation and creativity impressively. There are so many to say thank you to. The parliament and elected officials in both municipalities and regions have put everyday disagreements aside and worked for the common good. Of course, there have also been discussions. And criticism. There must be. But as Hal Koch really said it was already in 1945. Democracy is much more than a form of government. It's a way of life. It is not the polls that are the real strength of democracy. That's the conversation. And the will to find common solutions. We have reason to rejoice in how strong and living a democracy we have. Agreements and cooperation have created results to an unprecedented extent. In all parts of our community. We have proven a lot in 2020. Last spring, the economic prospects were gloomy. With the expectation that total economic activity would fall by more than five percent during the year. We prevented things from going so wrong. We showed that health and economy are closely related. Because limiting the infection is crucial to security. And thus that consumption and the economy will start again. We saw this over the summer, where we had a few months of significant financial progress. Well helped by auxiliary packages and other measures that held the hand under the purchasing power. The Danish economy has done better over the past year than we had first feared. Like unemployment has risen less than expected. More than half of the jobs in Denmark lost in the spring were won back in late summer. But as it often happens, the crisis has hit the unskilled hardest. We will do everything we can to make you come back to work as well. Maybe it requires you to train. Even if you don't have the best memories from school time. Then my invitation is anyway: Do it. It could be your way out of the crisis. * * * The pandemic has been a magnifying glass on our community. In Denmark. We've seen the weaknesses. But we have first and foremost shown the strengths of our social model. Persuasive. That we have managed it so far is no coincidence. This is due to the choices we made together. It is my wish for the future that everything we have accomplished will inspire us. I believe more than ever that we can jointly cope with the challenges we as a society have ahead of us. Also the very worst. Because if we can fight a global pandemic. Because we decide on it. Because we stand together. So think about everything else we can too. This applies to the climate, the environment and the nature. When a broad majority in the Folketing set the goal for greenhouse gases to be reduced by 70 percent by 2030. We had 10 years to reach the target. Now the first year has passed. And in just one year, we have already made decisions that bring us a third of the way. It's not as bad even as you say where I come from. We have decided a final date for our oil production. And with agreements on both electric cars, a green tax reform, offshore winds from energy islands, more waste sorting, 15 new natural parks, untouched forest and increased electrification, we are well on our way to fulfilling the promises we have made. Now we are going to start changing Danish agriculture to even more climate -friendly production. And as the world opens again, the demand for green solutions will rise. It is now that we need to combine Danish business, research and high climate ambitions. The green transition must succeed. And we can succeed. Denmark must show the world that politics matters. We need to stand by what we believe in. This also applies in foreign policy. As a society, we must take more character. Stand firmly on our Danish values. We must not accept that democracy is laid for hatred in parallel societies. Radicalization should not be protected. It must be revealed. The government will rethink the integration efforts so that it is increasingly based on clear demands and clear expectations. Focusing on right and duty. Basically, it must be so that when you have been staying in Denmark, you must of course support yourself. If this is not possible for a period of time, the government will suggest that - in return for its benefit - be obliged to contribute what corresponds to a regular work week of 37 hours. These are some of the tasks that are ahead of us in the new year. Tonight, I will also talk more about a topic that is filling less in the public debate. The context across our country. Almost every other Dane lives outside the larger cities. Denmark is so small. That wherever you are. Then you are never more than 50 kilometers from the sea. Still, the possibilities have been more skewed. You can no longer become a teacher in Haslev. Now you have to go to Roskilde or Vordingborg. You can no longer attend business school in Maribo. Now the closest place is Nakskov or Nykøbing. In many cities that previously had a hospital, it has been closed. Kalundborg. Faaborg. Haderslev. Dronninglund. Police stations are closed down. Some say that "such is the development". But that is not development. It's in many places settlement. And we can change that - if we want to. In a way that we do not have to create false contradictions. I am proud of our capital. Copenhagen is a fantastic city. The rest of the world envy us the harbor you can swim in. The bike paths. The art and culture. A city that still houses its own population and where there is also life and housing in the middle of the city. We must both have a strong capital. Well -functioning provincial cities. Small urban communities. And living rural areas. Jutland, Zealand, Funen and the islands can do something other than the capital. Nature is closer. The smaller communities often experience a strong community. Maybe both the clock and the heart beat a little calmer. In Copenhagen we need more homes that are payable. And less noise and pollution from traffic. In other parts of the country, the challenges are some others. Over the coming years, we will therefore open 20 new local police stations. Nine in Jutland. Nine in Zealand. Two on Funen. In the new year, we will establish more opportunities for young people to educate locally - close to where they live and come from. We also address the problem that too many Danes do not have the opportunity to get their own GP. This is especially true at Lolland-Falster, in West Zealand, in North Jutland and in parts of the larger cities-including some residential areas in Copenhagen. Police. Education. Medical coverage. There must be welfare throughout the country. It's also about the economy. Therefore, the government will propose an actual "welfare law". It must - if adopted - ensure that the money comes along. Fortunately, when we become more children and more older ones. In this way we hold our hand under welfare throughout the country. Probably gravity is a law of nature. But it is not centralization. * * * 100 years ago, Denmark and the world were also affected by a pandemic. It was "the Spanish sick". One who lived back then has portrayed it like this: “There is home (…), where they are sick all and no one has to help; They have to crawl out of the beds and help each other. " "There are none of the care, and doctors barely either." It is the author Martin Andersen Nexø. He also describes how "corpses drove gallop through the streets to overcome the many deaths." It clearly shows the difference between that time and today. Back then, it was missing Denmark that we have now. The welfare society that generations before us have built. During the pandemic we fight for them - for you - who have laid the stones to the community we others enjoy. And which is in the front row when the disease demands its victims. If anyone doubted that Denmark was found. As a community. As country. So don't doubt anymore. My speech tonight is a tribute to Denmark. To all of you who together make up our lovely country. 2020 is a year we will never forget. And yes - January and February get tough. But then comes the spring. The beech pops out. The birds come again. For summer the bright nights. 2021 will be better. Thanks to everyone in Denmark for the effort. Happy New Year!

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale ved pressemøde om anden coronanedlukning
speeches_dk: Velkommen til Situationen omkring corona udvikler sig, og den er desværre meget alvorlig.  Smittetallene er høje. Mere end 22.000 er konstateret smittede den seneste uge mod omkring 15.000 ugen før. Det hører med til historien, at rigtig mange danskere bliver testede, ca. 700.000 i den seneste uge. Men vi kan desværre se, at andelen af positive prøver har været stigende.  Vi er nu gået i det, der kaldes risikoniveau 4 i hele landet. Det næsthøjeste niveau. Dvs. at myndighederne vurderer, at der er udbredt samfundssmitte.  Det såkaldte kontakttal er 1,2. Altså 10 personer smitter 12 nye personer.  Det er et højt tal, fordi der nu er så mange smittede, som der er, og smitten derfor risikerer at stige endnu mere.  Samtidig må vi også sige, at sundhedsvæsenet er under pres, indlæggelsestallet for i dag er alarmerende højt, vi nærmer os nu 500 indlagte.  Det betyder, at flere planlagte operationer nu vil blive udskudt, og det betyder også, at det personale, vi er så afhængige af, skal løbe endnu hurtigere.  Knap halvdelen af de medicinske sengepladser til coronapatienter er nu i brug, og sundhedsmyndighederne forventer, at antallet af indlagte vil stige yderligere i den kommende tid.  Regeringen og myndigheder følger udviklingen meget, meget tæt.  Vi vurderer den i døgndrift, myndighederne skruer hele tiden op for testkapaciteten, og regereringen er klar til at handle på smitteudviklingen med få timers varsel. Det er nu en uge siden, at vi lukkede Danmark delvist ned.  Restriktionerne berørte til at starte med ca. halvdelen af den danske befolkning, de er nu udvidet til at gælde hele Danmark.  Der er heldigvis nogle tegn på, at de begynder at have lidt effekt.  Der er færre mennesker, der rejser i myldretiden, vi kan se, der igen er mere fokus på afstand, det er positivt.  Og det viser, at jeres indsats hver især, vores indsats sammen, den virker, det er bare ikke nok.  Vi skal have aktiviteten i samfundet yderligere ned.  Opgaven for os alle hver især, det er at få brudt smittekæderne, og dermed redde menneskeliv.  Derfor indfører vi i dag nye landsdækkende restriktioner, som vil gælde til tiden efter nytår.  Og vi gør det nu, fordi hvis smitten er for udbredt, når vi fejrer julen, så vil det betyde, at epidemien vil tage endnu mere fart på det værst tænkelige tidspunkt, hvor vi ikke engang er halvvejs igennem vinteren, og hvor vi i øvrigt har årstiden imod os, og ikke som i foråret med os.  Myndighedernes forventning er, at januar og februar kan blive de hårdeste måneder i hele pandemien. Derfor skal vi gøre mere, og vi skal gøre det nu.  Vi gør det, vi gør i dag, fordi det næsten ikke er til at bære, at vi så tæt på en vaccine, som vi er nu, risikerer, at der er ældre og sårbare, som bliver smittet, med risiko for at de bliver alvorligt syge.  Men vi gør også det, vi gør i dag, fordi at en epidemi, der løber ud af kontrol, vil have markant flere og mere alvorlige konsekvenser for samfundsøkonomien end de omkostninger, vi må tåle ved at lukke mere ned nu.  Dansk økonomi har indtil videre klaret sig bedre, end vi overhovedet har turdet håbe på.  Fordi vi har vist i Danmark, at sundhed og økonomi ikke er hinandens modsætninger, de er faktisk hinandens forudsætninger. Og det er stadigvæk tilfældet. Det grundlæggende budskab i dag er, at fra første juledag altså den 25. december og frem til 3. januar, da vil Danmark reelt være lukket helt ned.  Ud over alle de restriktioner, vi allerede kender nu, fx at restauranterne er lukket, at kultur og fritidsliv er lukket ned, så skal detailhandlen også holde lukket.  Det gælder pånær der, hvor vi køber vores dagligvarer og apoteker og lignende.  Allerede nu vil der igangsættes yderligere initiativer.  Allerede fra den 21. december, der sendes de skolebørn og -elever, der ikke allerede er gået på ferie, hjem. Det gælder også for fritidshjem og klubtilbud. Og liberale enhverv: frisører, massører, køreskoler osv. skal ligeledes holde lukket allerede fra på mandag, den 21. december.  Fra og med i morgen tidlig den 17. december, der lukker alle indkøbscentre, stormagasiner, butiksarkader og lignende.  Dermed lukkes butikker liggende de steder som udgangspunkt, medmindre der er tale om dagligvarebutikker, apoteker mv., eller der er direkte adgang til butikken ude fra gaden.  Men som udgangspunkt lukkes storcentrene ned fra i morgen tidlig. Alle de restriktioner, vi kommer til at gøre rede for her i dag, løber til og med den 3. januar 2021.  Når storcentre fra i morgen lukkes ned, så ved vi godt, at julehandlen til dels vil blive flyttet over i de butikker, som har åbnet frem til jul.  Det gør det endnu vigtige, at I forretningsdrivende sikrer den nødvendige afstand mellem kunderne, hygiejnen, og at vi som handlende tager et endnu større hensyn til hinanden og lytter til myndighedernes anbefalinger om eksempelvis højst at handle ind én fra hver familie.  Alt det her vil sundhedsministeren uddybe. De her tiltag – den nye nedlukning af Danmark – vil ramme mange virksomheder og lønmodtagere hårdt, på et tidspunkt hvor vi har været igennem allerede mange måneder, som har været svære.  Jeg ved, at det kan virke uoverskueligt.  I sidste uge blev regeringen og arbejdsmarkedets parter enige om at genindføre lønkompensation i hele landet, for alle brancher.  Det blev fulgt op af en bred aftale med Folketingets partier om at genåbne de generelle hjælpepakker fra foråret, kompensation for faste omkostninger og til selvstændige.  Tak til Folketinget for et godt og et hurtigt og et konstruktivt samarbejde.  Vi ved, at det her rammer særligt hårdt for mange i detailhandlen og blandt erhvervsdrivende, fordi julehandlen er et højdepunkt på året.  Allerede aften inviterer vi til forhandlinger om eventuelle yderligere tiltag, det vil beskæftigelsesministeren uddybe om lidt.  Når det gælder selve juleaften, så er det fortsat sundhedsstyrelsens anbefaling, at vi ikke holder jul med flere end højst ti personer, herunder at vi kan se den allernærmeste familie, også selvom vi måske ikke har været sammen med dem lige for nylig.  Generelt gælder myndighedernes anbefaling om, at vi højst samles 10 personer på en gang også i privat hjem, og at vi i det hele taget højst bør have en omgangskreds i den her tid på ti forskellige personer.  Og jeg vil gerne have lov til at understrege, at det her er ikke en opfordring til at samles ti personer, snarere tvært imod.  Derfor må vi også forvente, at både julen og nytåret bliver anderledes.  Det vil, hvad angår nytåret, ikke være rimeligt, med alle de omkostninger og begrænsninger, der kommer til at gælde nu, at vi sætter indsatsen over styr på årets sidste dag.  Derfor vil myndighederne i starten af næste uge melde klare anbefalinger ud i forhold til nytåret.  Kære allesammen, det her ér alvorligt.  Jeg er for at sige det ærligt dybt bekymret for, hvordan det kommer til at gå i de kommende vintermåneder, som meget vel kan gå hen at blive den allersværeste tid i vores fælles kamp mod coronaen.  Vi har en mulighed nu, måske den bedste vi får, for at undgå en situation, hvor vi i Danmark mister kontrollen med epidemien.  Hvis det går galt, så kommer det til at ramme os allesammen.  Der vil være andre sygdomme, som ikke bliver opdaget, der vil være endnu flere danskere, der kommer til at miste deres job, der vil være virksomheder, som vil være tvunget til at lukke.  Vi kom igennem foråret. Det var hårdt, men vi klarede det bedre, end vi havde frygtet.  Vi kom igennem sommeren, holdt smitten nede ved at blive i Danmark og passe på hinanden. Og vi er kommet nådigt igennem efteråret, hvor man i andre lande havde udgangsforbud, så kunne vi i Danmark stadigvæk gå i biografen og i fitnesscentret.  Og nu står vi så her ved afslutningen af året med en vaccine inden for rækkevidde – et lys der bliver tændt i mørket.  Til syvende og sidst er der kun en ting, der rigtig virker imod coronaen. Det er, at du og jeg og vi allesammen bliver ved med at tage ansvar for os selv og for hinanden.  Ingen restriktion kan i sig selv bremse pandemien.  Det er, når alt kommer til alt, vores egne handlinger og vores egne valg, som afgør, hvor godt Danmark kommer igennem krisen Og jeg vil derfor gerne bede alle danskere om, at vi nu igen viser den styrke og det samfundssind, som fik os godt igennem foråret, hjælper hinanden med at holde modet oppe og smitten nede.  Vi kan godt være mindre sammen uden at føle os alene, især hvis vi passer på hinanden, selvom det er med afstand. Vi viste det i foråret.  Jer, der har styrken, ressourcerne og netvæket, det er nu, vi har brug for jer til at hjælpe alle dem, som føler sig alene eller nedkørt.  Vi må hjælpe hinanden igennem det her og ud på den anden side af pandemien. Og med de ord vil jeg gerne have lov til i første omgang at give ordet videre til sundhedsministeren.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech at a press conference on other coronant closure
speeches_EN: Welcome to the situation around Corona develops and unfortunately it is very serious. The infection numbers are high. More than 22,000 have been found infected in the past week against about 15,000 the week before. It is part of the story that many Danes are tested, approx. 700,000 in the past week. But unfortunately we can see that the proportion of positive tests has been increasing. We have now gone into what is called risk level 4 throughout the country. The second highest level. Ie that the authorities believe that there is widespread community infection. The so -called contact number is 1.2. So 10 people infect 12 new people. It is a high number because there are now as many infected as there are, and therefore the infection risks rising even more. At the same time, we must also say that the health care system is under pressure, the inpatient figure for today is alarmingly high, we are now approaching 500 inpatients. This means that more planned operations will now be postponed, and it also means that the staff we are so dependent on will run even faster. Almost half of the medical beds for corona patients are now in use, and the health authorities expect the number of inpatients to rise further in the coming time. The government and authorities follow the development very, very closely. We evaluate it 24 hours a day, the authorities are constantly turning up the test capacity, and the government is ready to act on the development of infection with a few hours' notice. It is now a week ago that we closed down Denmark partially. The restrictions affected to start with approx. Half of the Danish population, they are now expanded to apply to all of Denmark. Fortunately, there are some signs that they are starting to have some effect. There are fewer people traveling during rush hour, we can see that again there is more focus on distance, it is positive. And it shows that your efforts each, our efforts together, it works, it's just not enough. We need to have the activity in the community down further. The task for all of us, is to break the infection chains, and thus save human life. Therefore, today we are introducing new nationwide restrictions that will apply to the time after the New Year. And we are doing it now because if the infection is too widespread when we celebrate Christmas, it will mean that the epidemic will take even more momentum at the worst possible time when we are not even halfway through the winter and where we have the season against us, and not as in the spring with us. The expectation of the authorities is that January and February can be the toughest months in the entire pandemic. That's why we need to do more and we need to do it now. We do what we do today because it is hardly impossible to carry that we are so close to a vaccine as we are now, the risk of being older and vulnerable who are infected, with the risk of being seriously ill. But we also do what we do today because an epidemic that runs out of control will have significantly more and more serious consequences for the social economy than the costs we have to endure by shutting down more now. The Danish economy has so far managed better than we have dared to hope for. Because we have shown in Denmark that health and economy are not each other's contradictions, they are actually each other's prerequisites. And that is still the case. The basic message today is that from the first Christmas Day on December 25 and until January 3, then Denmark will actually be completely shut down. In addition to all the restrictions we already know now, for example, that the restaurants are closed, that culture and leisure are shut down, the retailer must also keep closed. This applies to where we buy our groceries and pharmacies and the like. Already, additional initiatives will be initiated. Already from December 21, the schoolchildren and students who have not already gone on vacation are sent home. This also applies to leisure homes and club offers. And liberal everywhere: Hairdressers, masseurs, driving schools, etc. should also be closed already on Monday, December 21st. As of tomorrow morning, December 17, closing all shopping malls, department stores, shop arcades and the like. Thus, stores are closed to the places as a starting point, unless there are grocery stores, pharmacies, etc., or there is direct access to the store from the street. But as a starting point, the major centers will be shut down from tomorrow morning. All the restrictions we are going to explain here today runs until January 3, 2021. When major centers from tomorrow are shut down, we know well that the Christmas shopping will partly be moved into the stores that have opened until Christmas. It makes it still important that in businessmen, the necessary distance between customers, hygiene, and that we as traders take an even greater consideration of each other and listen to the authorities' recommendations, for example, to trade one from each family, for example. All this will elaborate on the Minister of Health. These initiatives - the new shutdown of Denmark - will hit many companies and employees hard, at a time when we have been through already many months that have been difficult. I know it may seem incomprehensible. Last week, the government and the social partners agreed to reintroduce wage compensation throughout the country, for all industries. It was followed by a broad agreement with the parliamentary parties to reopen the general aid packages from spring, compensation for fixed costs and to self -employed. Thank you to the Folketing for a good and a quick and a constructive collaboration. We know that this hits particularly hard for many in retail and among traders because the Christmas shopping is a highlight of the year. Already evening we invite you to negotiations on any further action, this will elaborate on the Minister of Employment. When it comes to Christmas Eve itself, it remains the National Board of Health's recommendation that we do not have Christmas with more than a maximum of ten people, including that we can see the very closest family, even if we may not have been with them just recently. In general, the authorities' recommendation that we are gathered at a maximum of 10 people at one time also in private homes, and that we should at all at most have a circle of people in this time of ten different people. And I would like to emphasize that this is not a call to gather ten people, rather the contrary. Therefore, we must also expect both Christmas and New Year to be different. As far as the New Year is concerned, it will not be reasonable, with all the costs and restrictions that will now be the case that we are putting our efforts on the last day of the year. Therefore, at the beginning of next week, authorities will announce clear recommendations compared to the New Year. Dear everyone, this is serious. I am to say it honestly deeply worried about how it will go in the coming winter months, which may well be the very worst time in our joint fight against the corona. We have an opportunity now, maybe the best we get to avoid a situation where we in Denmark lose control of the epidemic. If things go wrong, then it's going to hit us all. There will be other diseases that will not be discovered, there will be even more Danes who are going to lose their jobs, there will be companies that will be forced to close. We got through the spring. It was tough, but we did better than we had feared. We got through the summer, kept the infection down by staying in Denmark and looking after each other. And we have come graciously through the autumn, when other countries had a curfew, so in Denmark we could still go to the cinema and the gym. And now we stand here at the end of the year with a vaccine within easy reach - a light that will be lit in the dark. Ultimately, there is only one thing that really works against the corona. It is that you and I and we all keep taking responsibility for ourselves and for each other. No restriction can in itself slow down the pandemic. It is, after all, our own actions and our own choices, which determines how well Denmark comes through the crisis and I would therefore like to ask all Danes that we now show again the strength and the community that got us well through the spring helps each other keep the courage up and the infection down. We can be less together without feeling alone, especially if we look after each other, even if it is by distance. We showed it in the spring. You who have the strength, resources and the network, it is now that we need you to help all those who feel alone or descended. We must help each other through this and out on the other side of the pandemic. And with those words, I would like to be allowed to pass on to the Minister of Health in the first place.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale ved pressemøde om delvis nedlukning af 38 kommuner
speeches_dk: Velkommen her til pressemøde i Statministeriet. Smittetrykket i Danmark er for højt. Den stigning, vi har set igennem den seneste tid, er bekymrende. De sidste syv dage har vi i alt 12.041 nye smittede i Danmark. Region Hovedstaden er særligt hårdt ramt. Her er situationen nu så alvorlig, at myndighederne har hævet risikoen til niveau fire ud af fem i varslingssystemet.  Vi vil på pressemødet her i dag komme med tre meldinger: For det første vil vi fortælle, hvad der vil gælde, og hvad myndighederne vil opfordre til i forhold til jul og nytår.  For det andet vil vi forlænge de landsdækkende restriktioner, der allerede er kendt. Og for det tredje vil fri fra på onsdag indføre nye restriktioner og delvise nedlukninger regionalt og lokalt i 38 af landets kommuner. Men jeg vil gerne have lov til at begynde med at sige: Jeg ved godt, at dagens meldinger vil være nedslående for mange. Vinteren er kun lige startet. Vi har nogle kolde og hårde måneder foran os. Og nu bliver det med endnu flere begrænsninger. Men der er også et andet perspektiv på det, vi står overfor. Nemlig, at det i virkeligheden er ret utroligt, at det ikke har været nødvendigt at gøre det, vi gør i dag, før; at vi er kommet så langt i efteråret og i vinteren, som vi er.  Alt det er kun lykkedes på grund af en fantastisk, fælles, stor indsats og i virkeligheden på trods af omstændighederne.  For det, vi kæmper imod, er virus. Det er biologi. Det er en global pandemi, og i takt med at det bliver koldere, så rykker vi indenfor, og så får virus bare bedre betingelser. Men på en eller anden måde kæmper vi jo faktisk også lidt imod vores egen natur. Behovet for at mødes med andre mennesker, være sociale og omgås hinanden. Vi kæmper nok i virkeligheden også nu med lysten til at give slip og give op. Alligevel, så er vi lykkedes, så godt som vi er i Danmark. Den måde vi som land og som folk har valgt at håndtere coronakrisen på, det er en succeshistorie. I foråret, der bankede vi smitten ned hurtigt og effektivt. Hen over sommeren blev der sat ind lokalt. Først oppe i Hjørring, Ringsted og Aarhus. I efteråret indførte vi nogle nye, landsdækkende restriktioner og stabiliserede smitteudviklingen. Senest har der været en imponerende indsats i Nordjylland, og kombinationen af det med at teste, opspore og isolere vores adfærd hver især og de tidlige restriktioner, ja, det har faktisk virket hver eneste gang, vi har gjort det her i Danmark.  Det har også betydet, at vi herhjemme har kunnet opretholde en mere normal hverdag end det, man har kunnet opleve i mange andre lande. Mange steder i Europa er virkeligheden udgangsforbud, det er omfattende nedlukninger, og nogle steder har man fået at vide, at det at se én person ud over ens familie, det er at se én person for meget.  Herhjemme er både vores folkesundhed og vores økonomi kommet bedre igennem 2020, end vi faktisk havde turdet håbe på. Men nu er vi et rigtigt alvorligt sted i epidemien. Det vil sundhedsmyndighederne uddybe om lidt. Jeg vil nøjes med at sige det kort: Smitten, den er for høj, og situationen er for bekymrende. Derfor skal vi sætte ind, sådan at vi får kontrol med smitten og dermed med epidemien. Og det skal vi ikke mindst, fordi at der nu er meget kort tid tilbage til jul.  Julen er en højtid, der har kæmpestor betydning for stort set alle os danskere. Jeg ved godt, julen også kan være stress og jag, og den kan være hård, hvis man i forvejen kæmper med ensomhed eller har det svært. Men først og fremmest er julen jo et budskab om kærlighed; om at vi passer på hinanden, og det budskab er i år endnu vigtigere, end det plejer at være. Derfor har vi selvfølgelig også et meget stort ønske om, at vi alle sammen kan få lov til at holde en jul med dem, vi holder af. Det har vi brug for, og det til trods for, at det bliver en jul, der for mange af os bliver anderledes, end den plejer at være. Hvis smitten er for høj, når vi går ind i juleferien, så risikerer vi at miste kontrollen over smitten, og vi risikerer også, at epidemien løber løbsk, når vi kommer ind i januar og februar. Det må ikke ske. Derfor har vi valgt at forlænge de restriktioner, der ellers ville udløbe i de kommende uger. Det betyder blandt andet, at forsamlingsforbuddet på ti personer fastholdes, og det er myndighedernes klare anbefaling, at man også privat højst bør samle ti personer. Samtidig er det afgørende, hvor mange mennesker vi hver især ses med. Det betyder noget, hvor mange forskellige mennesker vi ser, og generelt gælder rådet jo, at jo færre mennesker vi ser, jo bedre kan vi også bryde smittekæderne. Når det gælder selve juleaften, så er det Sundhedsstyrelsens anbefaling, at vi kan se den allernærmeste familie, også selvom vi måske ikke har været sammen med dem for nylig, men altså stadig med en opfordring til, at vi ikke holder jul med flere end højst ti personer. For jer, der skal holde juleaften på et plejehjem eller et socialt tilbud, så vil der gælde nogle særlige retningslinjer, så I også får mulighed for at holde en god jul. Det samme gælder julearrangementer for hjemløse eller socialt udsatte. Sundhedsstyrelsen vil om lidt sige noget mere om julen, og sundhedsministeren vil sige noget om nytår.  Vi kan snart lægge 2020 bag os. Vaccinen, den er på vej, lyset er tændt. Forhåbentlig bliver det i 2021, hvor vi kan tage afsked med de begrænsninger, som coronaen har medført, så vi omsider kan vende tilbage til en mere normal hverdag igen. Men inden vi når så langt, så står vi over for nogle hårde måneder. Vi har den her gang årstiden imod os, og myndighedernes vurdering er desværre, at januar og februar kan blive nogle meget svære måneder i den her globale pandemi. Derfor vil de nationale restriktioner allerede nu blive forlænget til og med 28. februar 2021. Det gælder blandt andet forsamlingsforbuddet, opfordringen til at arbejde hjemme, krav om brug af mundbind eller visir og restriktioner i forhold til restauranter, detailhandel med videre. Det er de restriktioner, vi allerede kender og har levet med i efterhånden et stykke tid. De her restriktioner er desværre ikke tilstrækkelige i de dele af landet, hvor smitten nu stiger, og hvor den stiger for hurtigt. Det gælder København og alle kommuner i Region Hovedstaden med undtagelse af Bornholm. Det gælder Aarhus, og det gælder Odense. Og det gælder kommunerne på Sjælland: Greve, Solrød, Køge, Roskilde, Lejre, Slagelse, Faxe og Vordingborg. Det er i alt 38 kommuner, hvor smitten er så høj, at vi bliver nødt til at sætte ind med yderligere. Her vil vi fra onsdag d. 9. december, altså om to dage, indføre en delvis nedlukning, der gælder frem til og med 3. januar. I de 38 kommuner gælder nu, at skoleelever fra 5. klasse og opefter, og det vil også sige elever og kursister på ungdomsuddannelser, på voksenuddannelser samt videregående uddannelser, I bliver sendt hjem og skal herfra undervises digitalt. Børnene i vuggestuer og daginstitutioner, elever fra 0.- 4. klasse og sårbare børn og unge kan fortsætte pasning eller skolegang. Restauranter, caféer og andre serveringssteder skal holdes lukket, der må dog stadig godt sælges takeaway. Indedørs idræts-, forenings- og fritidssfaciliteter skal holdes lukket. Det gælder fx idrætshaller, svømmehaller, trænings- og fitnesscentre og spillehaller. Den professionelle idræt er undtaget. Kulturinstitutioner, teatre, spillesteder, museer, biografer og biblioteker skal holde indendørsarealer lukkede. Offentlige arbejdsgivere opfordres til at hjemsende alle medarbejdere, der ikke varetager kritiske funktioner, og private arbejdsgivere opfordres kraftigt til at sikre, at medarbejdere, der har mulighed for at varetage deres arbejde uden fysisk fremmøde på arbejdspladsen, gør det i den kommende tid.  På coronasmitte.dk vil der være et fuldt overblik over alle restriktionerne, både dem, der gælder lokalt, regionalt, og dem, der gælder på landsplan. Og de berørte erhverv vil selvfølgelig blive omfattet af hjælpepakker, som Folketingets partier og arbejdsmarkedets parter har arbejdet med allerede.  Jeg og vi ved godt, at de her nye restriktioner kommer til at trække veksler på Danmark igen. Det er igen med kort varsel, og det betyder, at alle jer, der skal få det til at fungere, igen har kort tid til, ja, at få det til at fungere. Og rigtig mange mennesker vil blive ramt af det her. I må bare ikke være i tvivl om, at det nytter. Det har nordjyderne lige vist os. På bare få uger, der fik Nordjyderne banket smittetallet ned. Da smitten var højest i slutningen af oktober var der 340 smittede på en uge i de syv kommuner, der var berørt. I den seneste uge var tallet faldet til 60 personer. Og jeg vil igen, på endnu et pressemøde som i dag, bede hver eneste af jer om at gøre en særlig indsats i den kommende tid. Det gælder ikke mindst alle jer, alle os, der bor i de 38 kommuner, der nu bliver mødt med ekstra restriktioner og nedlukninger. Til hver enkelt af jer vil jeg gerne sige: ved igen at give jeres bidrag. Ved at blive hjemme i stedet for at gå ud, så er du med nu til at bryde smittekæderne. Du er med til at sikre, at flere danskere kan se ind i at holde en god jul, hvor man ikke bliver smittet med corona. I sidste ende, så er du med til at redde liv i vores land. Så simpelt er det. Kære Danmark: Vi klarede foråret, vi klarede sommeren, vi klarede også efteråret. Og jeg er sikker på, at vi også kommer til at klare vinteren.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech at a press conference on partial shutdown of 38 municipalities
speeches_EN: Welcome here to a press conference in the Ministry of State. The infection pressure in Denmark is too high. The increase we have seen in recent times is worrying. For the past seven days we have a total of 12,041 new infected in Denmark. The Capital Region is particularly severely affected. Here, the situation is now so severe that the authorities have raised the risk to level four out of five in the warning system. At the press conference here today, we will come up with three messages: First, we will tell what will apply and what the authorities would urge for Christmas and New Year. Secondly, we will extend the nationwide restrictions already known. And third, free from Wednesday will introduce new restrictions and partial shutdowns regionally and locally in 38 of the country's municipalities. But I would like to start by saying: I know well that today's messages will be condescending to many. Winter has only just started. We have some cold and tough months ahead of us. And now it will be with even more restrictions. But there is also another perspective on what we are facing. Namely, it is in fact quite incredible that it has not been necessary to do what we do today before; That we have come as far in the fall and in the winter as we are. All of that has only succeeded because of a fantastic, common, great effort and in fact despite the circumstances. For what we are fighting against is virus. It's biology. It is a global pandemic and as it gets colder, we move inside, and then viruses just get better conditions. But somehow, we are actually struggling a little against our own nature. The need to meet with other people, be social and socialize. In fact, we are also struggling now with the desire to let go and give up. Still, we have succeeded as well as we are in Denmark. The way we as a country and as people have chosen to handle the corona crisis is a success story. In the spring, we knocked the infection down quickly and effectively. Over the summer, locally were deployed. First up in Hjørring, Ringsted and Aarhus. In the fall, we introduced some new, nationwide restrictions and stabilized the development of infection. Most recently, there has been an impressive effort in North Jutland, and the combination of testing, tracking and isolating our behavior each and the early restrictions, yes, it has actually worked every single time we have done this in Denmark. It has also meant that we have been able to maintain a more normal everyday life at home than what one has been able to experience in many other countries. Many places in Europe are the reality curfew, it is extensive shutdowns, and in some places you have been told that seeing one person in addition to one's family is to see one person too much. At home, both our public health and our economy have come better through 2020 than we had actually dared to hope for. But now we are a really serious place in the epidemic. The health authorities will elaborate on this. I just want to say it briefly: the infection, it is too high and the situation is too worrying. Therefore, we must put in so that we get control of the infection and thus with the epidemic. And we should not least because there is now a very short time back for Christmas. Christmas is a holiday that has a huge impact on virtually all of us Danes. I know Christmas can also be stress and rush, and it can be tough if you already struggle with loneliness or have a hard time. But first and foremost, Christmas is a message of love; that we look after each other and this message is even more important this year than it usually is. Therefore, of course, we also have a very great desire that we can all be allowed to have a Christmas with those we love. We need that, and despite the fact that it will be a Christmas that will be different for many of us than it usually is. If the infection is too high when we enter the Christmas holidays, then we risk losing control of the infection, and we also risk the epidemic running smoothly as we enter January and February. It must not happen. Therefore, we have chosen to extend the restrictions that would otherwise expire in the coming weeks. This means, among other things, that the assembly ban of ten persons is maintained, and it is the clear recommendation of the authorities that one should also be privately assembled ten people. At the same time, it is crucial how many people we each see. It matters how many different people we see, and in general the council applies that the fewer people we see, the better we can break the infection chains. When it comes to Christmas Eve itself, it is the recommendation of the National Board of Health that we can see the very closest family, even if we may not have been with them recently, but still with a call that we will not hold Christmas with more than ten people. For those of you who have to spend Christmas Eve in a nursing home or a social offer, there will be some special guidelines so that you will also have the opportunity to have a Merry Christmas. The same goes for Christmas events for homeless or socially disadvantaged. The National Board of Health will say something more about Christmas, and the Minister of Health will say something about the New Year. We can leave 2020 behind us soon. The vaccine, it is on the way, the light is on. Hopefully it will be in 2021, when we can say goodbye to the limitations that the corona has led to, so that we can finally return to a more normal everyday life. But before we get that far, we face some tough months. We have this time the season against us, and the authorities' assessment is unfortunately that January and February can become some very difficult months in this global pandemic. Therefore, the national restrictions will already be extended through February 28, 2021. This applies, among other things, to the assembly ban, the invitation to work at home, requirements for the use of mouthwash or visor and restrictions in relation to restaurants, retail and so on. These are the restrictions we already know and have lived with for a while. Unfortunately, these restrictions are not sufficient in the parts of the country where the infection now rises and where it rises too fast. This applies to Copenhagen and all municipalities in the Capital Region with the exception of Bornholm. This applies to Aarhus, and this applies to Odense. And this applies to the municipalities in Zealand: Greve, Solrød, Køge, Roskilde, Lejre, Slagelse, Faxe and Vordingborg. There are a total of 38 municipalities where the infection is so high that we will have to put in place with further. Here we will introduce a partial shutdown that applies until 3 January from Wednesday, December 9, ie in two days. In the 38 municipalities, school students from 5th grade and upwards are now true, which means students and students in youth education, in adult education and higher education, you are sent home and must be taught digitally. The children in crèches and day care institutions, students from 0- 4th grade and vulnerable children and young people can continue care or schooling. Restaurants, cafes and other serving sites must be kept closed, but takeaway must still be sold. Indoor sports, association and leisure facilities must be kept closed. This applies, for example, to sports halls, swimming pools, training and fitness centers and gaming halls. The professional sport is exempt. Cultural institutions, theaters, venues, museums, cinemas and libraries must keep indoor areas closed. Public employers are encouraged to repeal all employees who do not perform critical functions, and private employers are strongly encouraged to ensure that employees who have the opportunity to take care of their work without physical attendance in the workplace do so in the coming time. At coronasmitte.dk there will be a full overview of all the restrictions, both those that apply locally, regionally, and those applicable nationwide. And, of course, the professions concerned will be covered by aid packages that the parties of the Folketing and the social partners have already worked with. I and we know well that these new restrictions will be drawn to Denmark again. It is again at short notice, and it means that all of you who have to make it work again have a short time, yes, to make it work. And a lot of people will be affected by this. You just don't have to doubt it. The North Jews have just shown us. In just a few weeks that got the North Jews knocked down. When the infection was highest in late October, there were 340 infected in a week in the seven municipalities affected. In the past week, the figure had dropped to 60 people. And again, at another press conference like today, I will ask every one of you to make a special effort in the coming time. This applies not least to all of you, all of us who live in the 38 municipalities that are now met with extra restrictions and shutdowns. To each of you I would like to say: By giving your contribution again. By staying home instead of going out, you are now in to break the infection chains. You help ensure that more Danes can look into having a merry Christmas where you are not infected with Corona. In the end, you are helping to save lives in our country. Simple as that. Dear Denmark: We managed the spring, we managed the summer, we also managed the fall. And I'm sure we're going to handle the winter too.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale på Facebook forud for pressemøde om delvis nedlukning
speeches_dk: Kære alle Det er anden søndag i advent, og her på Marienborg er der pyntet smukt op til jul. Nøjagtigt som det gælder i rigtig mange danske hjem over hele landet.  I fjernsynet er årets julekalendre kommet godt i gang, og det er blevet tid til i mange køkkener at få bagt klejner og vaniljekranse og brunkager. Nu mangler vi bare snart, at det også begynder at sne. Mon ikke vi allesammen glæder os særligt meget til julen lige præcis i år? Det gør jeg i hvert fald.  Tid til at være sammen med familien igen, og derfor har vi igen fået en fælles opgave i hele landet.  Vi skal have bedre styr på smitten, inden det bliver selve juleaften. Det kommer til at kræve meget af os allesammen, igen. Hvis vi generelt ser færre mennesker, så bliver det mere sikkert at kunne samle den nære familie, når det netop bliver juleaften.  At omgås hinanden mindre, det falder os bare ikke naturligt, og slet ikke efter de mange måneder med corona. Vi længes efter den sociale kontakt med vores venner og vores kolleger og vores familie. Men vi bliver nødt til at vente lidt endnu.  Og vi bliver nødt til at spørge os selv, "skal vi ses?", og ikke "hvordan kan vi ses?".  Vores adfærd hver især er igen helt afgørende, som det i øvrigt har været det igennem hele pandemien. Og det er restriktionerne også.  På baggrund af de indstillinger, vi får fra myndighederne, så har vi henover weekenden forberedt en geografisk målrettet og delvis nedlukning, desværre.  Det vil gælde i de dele af landet, hvor smitten, den er mest udbredt. Det omfatter København, Odense og Aarhus og en række kommuner i Hovedstaden og på Sjælland.  Den danske tilgang til corona er stadigvæk den samme. Vi skal sætte ind tidligt, så vi forhåbentligt undgår at skulle lukke endnu hårdere ned, hvis det en dag alligevel er for sent. Vi er lige nu i dialog med Folketingets partier om den her situation. Og i morgen, der vil vi – i morgen formiddag – præsentere de nye tiltag, ligesom vi vil sige mere om, hvad det er for nogle restriktioner, der vil gælde i hele landet hen over jul og nytår, og sådan set også resten af vinteren. Det gør vi på et pressemøde i Statsministeriet, jeg håber, du har mulighed for at se med og lytte med, indtil da rigtig god søndag aften.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech on Facebook prior to press conference on partial shutdown
speeches_EN: Dear all it is the second Sunday of Advent, and here at Marienborg is beautifully decorated for Christmas. Just as it applies in many Danish homes across the country. On television, this year's Christmas calendars have got off to a good start, and it is time to get baked cloves and vanilla wreaths and brownies in many kitchens. Now we are just missing soon that it starts to snow too. Wouldn't we all be very much looking forward to Christmas just this year? At least I do. Time to be with the family again, which is why we have again been given a common task throughout the country. We need to have better control of the infection before it becomes Christmas Eve itself. It's going to require a lot of us all, again. If we generally see fewer people, then it becomes safer to be able to gather the close family when it becomes Christmas Eve. To socialize with each other less, it just does not fall naturally, and not at all after the many months of Corona. We long for social contact with our friends and our colleagues and our family. But we have to wait a little longer. And we will have to ask ourselves, "should we see you?" And not "how can we see you?". Our behavior each is again absolutely crucial, as it has been throughout the pandemic. And so are the restrictions. Based on the settings we get from the authorities, we have prepared a geographically targeted and partial shutdown over the weekend. It will apply in those parts of the country where the infection it is most widespread. This includes Copenhagen, Odense and Aarhus and a number of municipalities in the capital and in Zealand. The Danish approach to Corona is still the same. We have to put in early so that hopefully we avoid having to shut down even harder if one day it is too late. We are currently in dialogue with the parties of the Folketing about this situation. And tomorrow, we will - tomorrow morning - present the new initiatives, just as we will say more about what some restrictions will apply throughout the country over Christmas and New Year, and so also the rest of the winter. We do this at a press conference in the Prime Minister, I hope you have the opportunity to watch and listen, until then really good Sunday night.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale ved pressemøde om nedlukning af Nordjylland
speeches_dk: Jeg vil gerne have lov til at sige velkommen til pressemødet. Den 11. marts var en skæbnestund i kampen mod corona i Danmark.  Den dag, der traf vi en svær men nødvendig beslutning, som vendte op og ned på alles hverdag i Danmark.  For jer i Nordjylland, der vil dagen i dag, 5. november, blive en mindst lige så skelsættende dato. De restriktioner, vi fremlægger nu, kommer til at få stor betydning for jer og for jeres hverdag. Derfor vil jeg i dag særligt henvende mig til jer, de mere end 280.000 borgere og nordjyder i de syv kommuner, der bliver berørt.  Det er Hjørring, det er Frederikshavn, det er Brønderslev, Jammerbugt, Vesthimmerland, det er Thisted, og så er det Læsø.  Hele Danmark kommer til at trække store veksler på jeres opbakning og på jeres tålmodighed og ja – på jeres samfundssind.  Baggrunden er, som de fleste ved, at der er fundet muteret coronavirus både i mink og hos mennesker.  Det indebærer en risiko for, at en kommende vaccine måske ikke kommer til at virke, som den skal.  Det er selvsagt meget alvorligt.  I går besluttede vi derfor, at den danske minkbestand skal aflives. Det var en tung dag for rigtig mange familier og for hele det danske minkerhverv.  Det har gjort et stort indtryk på mig, vil jeg gerne sige, at se, hvordan I minkavlere har håndteret den ulykkelige og meget svære situation. Tak for det.  Nu står vi så med den næste opgave, nemlig at inddæmme den smitte, som allerede er sket, også blandt mennesker.
