Fordi vi risikerer, at hvis vi ikke gør det her, så bliver omkostningerne både menneskeligt, sundhedsmæssigt og økonomisk langt, langt større.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech at press conference on border closure
speeches_EN: Welcome to a press conference here in the Prime Minister again. These days there is a really big responsibility on the shoulders of the Danes. And the responsibility you have taken on you. I would like to be allowed to say a big thank you for that. I find that the vast majority of Danes support the big and drastic decisions that have been made and that are making changes in everyone's everyday life now. The authorities will need your support again now, with new initiatives. And I need your patience. For we are here again to present a number of new initiatives in the efforts against Coronavirus. Before I present them, I would like to thank the heart for the social mind that you are exhibiting right now. For that social mind is a very large part of the solution that we get through this crisis that we are now in. We must stand together by keeping away. If too many people get infected at the same time, then we risk the health system breaking down, and that's what we're doing everything we can to avoid now. We need to help each other and so do the Danes. In help networks where vulnerable can call in and ask for help and where volunteers are ready to help. Educators and school teachers across the country are finding solutions for the children whose parents have to meet at work and cannot find any other care. Neighboring communities bloom. Thank you to the trade union movement and to the Danish business community, which is in the process of finding solutions for employees and for companies. It is a job that continues to go on and which the government takes very seriously. Thank you to police, emergency preparedness and home defense that everyone is already ready to help. And thanks to all of you that we rarely get mentioned when we say thank you. Namely, all of you who still help keep the wheels going. Which ensures that the Danes can shop can still use public transport. Although things are on reduced flare, there are quite a few social functions that are still underway. And a special thank you must of course sound to the employees of the health care system. In many places you are already burdened by the situation, you make a huge effort. Thank you. Right now we have a common really big task, which is about ensuring that too many people are not infected at the same time. The status right now is that 801 Danes have been found infected. 23 is now admitted to the hospital. 4 is in intensive treatment. And 2 is unfortunately in critical condition. These figures, both the number of infected, number of inpatients and Danes in critical condition, we must expect rises. Also rises a lot. And they come to that, even if we act. Because much of what we do now, hopefully we will see the effect of, but it will happen at a later date. And that is why all Danes must keep doing what we are well in the process of. Keep distance from each other, help each other. And take into account, not least to the most vulnerable. Of course, a lot of what we have started is about our health care system. Therefore, it is important, the decision made today, which is about avoiding a situation where hospitals and health care breaks down because of the burden that may arise as a result of Corona. All hospitals in Denmark have today been told to close all normal activity in the health care system. All that is not necessary must shut down now. We need to do this to prevent healthcare professionals from being infected. To prevent patients from infecting each other. But also to give time for the sideman's training that becomes absolutely necessary for healthcare professionals to cope with the situation when we are in a more critical situation. This is also going to have consequences for many Danes. Many will have their surgery postponed if it is not acute. I know it's going to be a nuisance for many. And that already means that we are going to look into a healthcare system that is also on the other side of Corona will be overburdened. All that we do at home; All the precautions that are taken are all the decisions we make. We risk them being undermined if we continue travel activity in and out of Denmark. For it increases the risk of continued infection. And therefore: New initiatives. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has already changed the travel guide today so that all non-nutritious trips to the whole world are advised. This means that one must not travel away from Denmark unless it is absolutely necessary. And if you are on holiday abroad, you have to find back to Denmark and comply with the rules that are too quarantined. In addition: New message. From tomorrow at. 12, which temporarily closes the Danish borders. It will still be possible and it will be absolutely necessary to transport food to Denmark, medicine and other supplies, such as are necessary for our industrial production. But all tourists, all travel, all holidays and all foreigners who cannot prove that they have a recognizable purpose when entering Denmark, they will in future be rejected on the Danish border. Danish citizens can always enter Denmark. With what we do here, we must expect in a short time to see a full or partially large shutdown of everything. Air transport, ferry transport, train transport. For all passenger traffic. Many Danes are going to be affected. There are some commuters in the border country from Sweden and Germany. You must expect longer cows and longer travel time. As with the closure of schools, the closure of the boundaries comes to take some time. The full border control we will only have run up in a few days. I would also already say that you should expect to see the defense at the border. Of course, it is the police who are responsible, but we will start to ask the Defense Personnel to be active in the border guard. Of course, there will be information campaigns for Danes abroad. And there will also be information campaigns for the countries where many foreigners come from when they come to Denmark. Freight transport is not covered by border control. And that's simply because we need to get as many foods and goods into the country as possible. We are in close contact with the transport industries to make this slide as well as possible. We have today informed the European Commission. And we have informed our neighboring countries, Norway, Sweden and Germany, about this decision. Border control is running so far through Easter. So up to and including April 13. And it also follows the sharpening that is also of the travel guides. So I hope everyone has heard not to go on Easter holidays out of Denmark this year. This is again serious initiatives. Once again. They won't be the last. And in a very short time we will make announcements, new announcements, such as must help Danish employees who, in the same way, as companies may face major challenges in the coming time. Compared to the whole, I would like to say that we are on untrusted country. We are in a situation that is not similar to something that some of us have tried before. It's going to get costs for all of us. I'm sure we get through this together in a good way. And right now I know that the overall catalog is very violent and will be experienced very violently. But I am of the clear conviction that it is worth it. Because we risk that if we do not do this, the costs will be human, health and financially far, far greater.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale ved pressemøde om første coronanedlukning
speeches_dk: Velkommen til pressemødet.   Det, jeg vil sige her i aften, vil få store konsekvenser for alle danskere.   Der vil komme svære situationer for mange borgere. Der bliver brug for, at vi hjælper hinanden.  Før jeg når til det, vil jeg indlede om den situation, vi ser ind i, og baggrunden for den.   Da jeg stod her i går, var 157 danskere smittede med corona.  I dag har vi 514 smittede.   Antallet er mere end en tidobling siden mandag, hvor tallet var 35 smittede.   Coronavirus spreder sig ekstremt hurtigt.   Italien er lukket ned. På hospitalerne mangler der respiratorer og personale.   Jeg vil gerne understrege: Det er ikke et skræmmebillede. Det er ikke et fantasifuldt udtænkt fremtidsscenarie.   Det er virkeligheden i et land, som de fleste af os kender. Hvor mange har været på ferie. Et land i Europa. I vores del af verden.   Vi har som myndigheder, borgere og som land lige nu én opgave, der er vigtigere end alle andre:   Vi skal undgå, at for mange bliver smittet på én gang. Som det er sket i Italien.   Det går allerede hurtigt herhjemme. For hurtigt.   Derfor intensiverer myndighederne indsatsen for at afbøde og forsinke smitten i Danmark.  Jeg vil igen understrege, at vi har en meget stor forpligtelse til især at hjælpe de svageste i vores samfund, de mest sårbare, mennesker med kroniske sygdomme, kræftpatienter, de ældre.   Af hensyn til dem må smitten ikke sprede sig.   Hvis mange bliver smittet, kan kapaciteten på intensivafdelingerne ikke følge med. Sundhedspersonalet kan ikke følge med. Ikke kun fordi sygehusene bliver overbelastede af kritisk syge mennesker. Men også fordi en stor del af plejepersonalet selv kan blive syge eller være i karantæne.   Det er præcis den situation, vi skal gøre alt, hvad vi kan, for at undgå.   Vi har bevæget os videre mod den næste fase i epidemien. Hvor smitten ikke kun kommer fra dem, der har været ude at rejse. Men hvor vi også er begyndt at smitte hinanden i Danmark.   Derfor skal vi tage stærkere midler i brug for at hindre smittespredning.   Det kan kun lykkes, hvis alle gør det sammen. Alles adfærd bliver afgørende.  Vi må alle sammen være klar over situationens alvor.   Den sundhedsfaglige smitteanalyse er, at der er én ting, der virker mod smitte.   Ikke at omgås hinanden for meget.   Vi skal stå sammen. Vi skal passe på hinanden. Men på en anden måde, end vi plejer.   Vi plejer som danskere at søge fællesskabet ved at være tæt sammen.   Nu skal vi stå sammen ved at holde afstand.   Vi får brug for samfundssind. Vi får brug for hjælpsomhed. Jeg vil gerne sige tak til borgere, virksomheder, arrangører, frivillige organisationer – alle, der indtil nu har vist, at det er præcis det, vi har i Danmark – samfundssind.   Det får vi brug for i de kommende uger.   Vi skal hellere handle i dag, end fortryde i morgen. Vi skal sætte ind dér, hvor det virker. Hvor smitten spredes mest.   Det er dér, hvor mange mennesker er samlet.  Daginstitutioner, skoler, uddannelsesinstitutioner.  Aktivitetstilbud, arrangementer. I den kollektive trafik.   Derfor er myndighedernes anbefaling, at vi lukker ned for al unødvendig aktivitet på de områder i en periode. Vi anlægger et forsigtighedsprincip.  Derfor tager myndighederne nu følgende skridt: Elever og studerende på alle uddannelsesinstitutioner sendes hjem nu. Og foreløbigt to uger fra fredag. Alle indendørs kulturinstitutioner, biblioteker og fritidstilbud lukker nu. Og foreløbigt to uger fra fredag. Alle private institutioner, frivillige foreninger, trossamfund mv. opfordres kraftigt til at gøre det samme. Alle offentligt ansatte, der ikke varetager kritiske funktioner, sendes hjem fra arbejde fra fredag og foreløbigt to uger. Det vil ske på den måde, at alle offentlige arbejdsgivere opfordres kraftigt til at sende flest muligt medarbejdere hjem nu. Flere er allerede i gang. Alle offentligt ansatte, der ikke varetager kritiske funktioner, skal sendes hjem.  De hjemsendte skal så vidt muligt arbejde hjemmefra. Men alle hjemsendte vil få løn i den offentlige sektor.   De, der ikke kan sendes hjem, er blandt andet personale i sundhedssektoren, ældresektoren, politiet og mennesker, der arbejder med socialt udsatte.   Lige præcis jer har vi mere brug for end nogensinde. Alle private arbejdsgivere opfordres kraftigt til at sikre, at flest muligt af jeres medarbejdere arbejder hjemmefra, afspadserer eller afholder ferie.  Vi skal minimere aktiviteten mest muligt. Men uden at sætte Danmark helt i stå. Vi skal ikke kaste Danmark ud i en økonomisk krise.   Så vi vælger ændringer i den offentlige sektor for at understøtte, at den private sektor kan fortsætte bedst muligt i længst mulig tid.  Og alle vi andre skal selvfølgelig kunne købe varer i butikkerne.   Der skal produceres, transporteres og sælges varer.  Og her vil jeg understrege: Vi er ikke i en fødevarekrise. Der er ingen grund til at hamstre rugbrød og toiletpapir. Heller ikke i morgen.   Alle skoler og dagtilbud lukkes fra på mandag og to uger frem.   Jeg vil opfordre alle forældre og familier til, at de, der allerede i morgen kan holde børnene hjemme – gør det. Så vi får en gradvis indfasning.   Hvordan skal børnefamilierne klare det? Vi må hjælpe hinanden.  Jeg vil opfordre familierne til allerede nu at tale om, hvad der kan lade sig gøre. Om far og mor kan møde forskudt. Om naboer, venner, familie kan passe. Vi bliver nødt til at hjælpe hinanden.  Skoler og institutioner vil blive holdt åbne til de forældre, der ikke kan finde en anden løsning.   Hvis man ikke har andre muligheder, så må man selvfølgelig møde op med sit barn. Så må skolen eller daginstitutionen finde ud af det. Det er ikke, fordi det er blevet farligt at gå i skole. Men der er en smitterisiko, når man er mange samlet.  Der vil også komme ordninger for de forældre, som er nødt til at tage på arbejde.   Men det hele vil ikke være på plads fra dag ét. Derfor appellerer jeg allerede nu til tålmodighed.   Vi skal begrænse anvendelse af kollektiv trafik. Vi er i gang med, at udbyderne tager de nødvendige initiativer for at sikre, at passagerer ikke står for tæt. Og det er begyndt at virke. Det har vi set i dag.   Nu gør vi mere. Der indføres pladsbilletkrav hos DSB på alle afgange på regional-, intercity- og lyntog.   Sygehuse og plejehjem opfordres til at begrænse besøgende. Med øjeblikkelig virkning. Det er vigtigt, at alle pårørende respekterer det. Myndighederne har før opfordret til, at man ikke samles mere end 1.000 mennesker. Nu lyder opfordringen herfra, at man ikke samler flere end 100 mennesker indendørs. Og til, at natklubber, diskoteker, værtshuse mv. holder lukket i en periode.   Vi har ikke hjemmel til at forbyde det, som lovgivningen er i dag. Men vi kommer til at bede Folketinget om at vedtage hastelovgivning allerede i morgen, og fra starten af næste uge udstedes et egentligt forbud.  Alle de drastiske ting, jeg har nævnt, betyder, at vi danskere kommer til at se mindre til hinanden. I første omgang i to uger.  Desuden skærper Udenrigsministeriet igen rejsevejledningerne. Der er allerede en række lande og områder, man ikke skal tage til. Det er Norditalien, Iran samt en række specifikke områder i Kina, Sydkorea, Østrig.   Nu tilføjes en række lande og regioner til listen.  Regeringen overvejer også at undersøge muligheden for at indføre yderligere restriktioner ved indrejse i Danmark. Det kan fx være tvungen helbredsundersøgelse, før man må komme ind i Danmark. Alt det her tilsammen får kæmpe konsekvenser for hele Danmark. Kæmpe konsekvenser.   Men alternativet – ikke at gøre noget – ville være langt værre. Det håber jeg på, at der vil være forståelse for. Det er jeg overbevist om, at der vil være.   Normalt ville en regering ikke gå ud med så indgribende meldinger uden at have løsningerne klar for alle berørte.   Men vi står i en helt ekstraordinær situation.   Jeg vil sige ærligt. Det rejser mange og helt relevante spørgsmål. Og hverken jeg selv eller myndighederne har alle svarene endnu.  Jeg vil også sige helt ærligt: Vi kommer ikke igennem det her uden omkostninger. Virksomheder vil opleve tab. Nogle vil miste deres arbejde.   Regeringen vil gøre, hvad vi kan for at afbøde konsekvenserne både for virksomheder og lønmodtagere. Vi er i dialog med arbejdsmarkedets parter om, hvordan vi gør det bedst.   Jeg vil desuden kraftigt opfordre alle sårbare borgere til at blive hjemme. Holde sig hjemme. Dem, som corona kan ramme særligt hårdt.   Alle, der er raske, har et kæmpe ansvar for de mest udsatte. Jeg hører mange steder fra, at mange allerede har organiseret sig. Fundet løsninger. Fx med, at naboen køber ind. Man laver mad til hinanden. Man holder øje og er opmærksom.  Lad os nu vise, hvad vi kan, når det gælder.  Danskerne er i gang. Vi udviser samfundssind. Det er det, der fungerer.   Meget af løsningen på det, vi står overfor, hviler på danskernes skuldre.   Jeg vil igen sige tak for et godt samarbejde med Folketingets partier.   Jeg har i aften holdt møde med partilederne og Folketingets formand om hastelovgivning på en række områder. Der er fuld opbakning til, at vi skal have de nødvendige redskaber klar i epidemiloven og anden lovgivning.   Til sidst kan jeg nævne, at jeg selv har gået min kalender igennem. Jeg vil ikke deltage i udadvendte aktiviteter de næste 14 dage. Det samme gælder mine ministre.   Når vi holder møder i Statsministeriet, sidder vi på hver anden stol. Ligesom her til pressemødet i dag.  Det er måske små ting. Men det er også summen af de små ting, der er en del af løsningen.  Jeg er klar over, at det, jeg, sammen med myndighederne, beder danskerne om i dag, er store ting. Meget indgribende.  Vi gør det, fordi det har effekt. Vi skal ikke gå i panik.  Vi må hjælpe hinanden. Vise overskud – tænke på andre. Særligt på dem, som er udsatte. Jeg vil takke alle i vores sundhedsvæsen for den kæmpe indsats, I yder. Tak for jeres indsats nu. Og på forhånd tak for jeres indsats i de kommende dage, uger og måneder.   Jeg vil sige det, som det er. Det bliver hårdt.  Situationen kommer til at stille kæmpe krav til os alle sammen.  Men selvfølgelig helt særlige krav til jer, der arbejder på vores sygehuse. På intensivafdelingerne. På højrisikostuerne.   Vi får meget, meget brug for jer i den allernærmeste fremtid.   Vi står på ubetrådt land. Vi står i en situation, som ikke ligner noget, vi har prøvet før.   Kommer vi til at begå fejl?   Ja.  Kommer jeg til at begå fejl?  Ja.  Jeg får brug for jeres tålmodighed. Vi kan ikke svare på alle spørgsmål lige nu. Men på flere, så hurtigt det kan lade sig gøre.  I morgen vil der være pressemøde med ressortministrene. Her vil også være mulighed for at stille spørgsmål.  Udmeldingen i dag bliver ikke de sidste initiativer fra myndighederne.   Vi skal alle gøre alt, hvad vi kan, for at passe på danskerne. På Danmark. På hinanden.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech at the press conference on first corona closure
speeches_EN: Welcome to the press conference. What I would say here tonight will have major consequences for all Danes. There will be difficult situations for many citizens. We need to help each other. Before I reach it, I will start about the situation we look into and the background of it. When I was standing here yesterday, 157 Danes were infected with Corona. Today we have 514 infected. The number is more than a doubling since Monday, when the figure was 35 infected. Coronavirus is spreading extremely quickly. Italy is shut down. In hospitals, respirators and staff are missing. I would like to emphasize: It's not a scare. It is not an imaginatively devised future scenario. It is the reality of a country that most of us know. How many have been on vacation. A country in Europe. In our part of the world. We, as authorities, citizens and as a country right now, have one task that is more important than everyone else: We must avoid too many being infected at once. As has happened in Italy. It is already going home quickly. Too fast. Therefore, the authorities intensify the efforts to mitigate and delay the infection in Denmark. Again, I would like to emphasize that we have a very big commitment to especially helping the weakest in our society, the most vulnerable, people with chronic illnesses, cancer patients, the elderly. For the sake of them, the infection must not spread. If many become infected, the capacity of the intensive care units cannot keep up. The healthcare staff cannot keep up. Not only because the hospitals are overloaded by critically ill people. But also because a large part of the nursing staff can get sick or be quarantined. This is exactly the situation we need to do everything we can to avoid. We have moved on towards the next phase of the epidemic. Where the infection not only comes from those who have been traveling. But where we have also started to infect each other in Denmark. Therefore, we must use stronger means to prevent the spread of infection. It can only succeed if everyone does it together. Everyone's behavior becomes crucial. We must all be aware of the seriousness of the situation. The healthcare professional infection analysis is that there is one thing that works against infection. Not to interact with each other too much. We have to stand together. We have to take care of each other. But in a different way than we usually do. As Danes, we usually seek the community by being close together. Now we have to stand together by keeping away. We need social minds. We will need helpfulness. I would like to say thank you to citizens, companies, organizers, voluntary organizations - all who have so far shown that this is exactly what we have in Denmark - social minds. We will need that in the coming weeks. We should rather act today than regret tomorrow. We need to put in where it works. Where the infection spreads most. That's where many people are gathered. Day care institutions, schools, educational institutions. Activity offering, events. In the public transport. Therefore, the recommendation of the authorities is that we shut down all unnecessary activity in those areas for a period of time. We apply a precautionary principle. Therefore, the authorities are now taking the following steps: Students and students at all educational institutions are being sent home now. And so far two weeks from Friday. All indoor cultural institutions, libraries and leisure offers are now closing. And so far two weeks from Friday. All private institutions, voluntary associations, religious communities, etc. is strongly encouraged to do the same. All public servants who do not perform critical functions will be sent home from work from Friday and for two weeks. It will happen in such a way that all public employers are strongly encouraged to send as many people as possible employees home now. More are already in the process. All public servants who do not perform critical functions must be sent home. The homes must work from home as far as possible. But all returned will receive pay in the public sector. Those who cannot be sent home are, among other things, staff in the health sector, the elderly sector, the police and the people working with socially vulnerable. Just exactly you we need more than ever. All private employers are strongly encouraged to ensure that as many of your employees work from home, leave or take a vacation. We need to minimize the activity as much as possible. But without putting Denmark completely. We are not going to throw Denmark into an economic crisis. So we choose changes in the public sector to support the private sector to continue as best as possible for the longest possible time. And all of us, of course, must be able to buy goods in the stores. It must be produced, transported and sold goods. And here I would like to emphasize: We are not in a food crisis. There is no need to hoard rye bread and toilet paper. Not tomorrow. All schools and daycare are shut off on Monday and two weeks ahead. I would encourage all parents and families that those who can already keep the kids home tomorrow - do it. So we get a gradual phase -in. How should the families of children do it? We have to help each other. I would urge the families to already talk about what can be done. Whether father and mother can meet staggered. About neighbors, friends, family can fit. We will have to help each other. Schools and institutions will be kept open to the parents who cannot find another solution. If you have no other options, then of course you have to meet with your child. Then the school or daycare must find out. It's not because going to school has become dangerous. But there is a risk of infection when you are many gathered. There will also be schemes for the parents who have to go to work. But it will not be in place from day one. That's why I'm already appealing to patience. We need to limit the use of public transport. We are in the process of taking the necessary initiatives to ensure that passengers are not too close. And it's started to work. We've seen that today. Now we do more. Space ticket requirements are introduced at DSB on all departures on regional, intercity and lightning trains. Hospitals and nursing homes are encouraged to limit visitors. With immediate effect. It is important that all relatives respect it. Authorities have previously called for no more than 1,000 people to gather. Now the invitation from here is that you do not collect more than 100 people indoors. And to the fact that nightclubs, discos, taverns, etc. keep closed for a period of time. We do not have the authority to ban what the legislation is today. But we are going to ask the Folketing to adopt rush legislation already tomorrow, and from the start of next week an actual ban is issued. All the drastic things I have mentioned means that we Danes are going to look less at each other. At first for two weeks. In addition, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is again tightening the travel guides. There are already a number of countries and areas not to go to. It is Northern Italy, Iran and a number of specific areas in China, South Korea, Austria. Now a number of countries and regions are added to the list. The government is also considering investigating the possibility of introducing additional restrictions on entry into Denmark. For example, it may be forced health examination before you have to enter Denmark. All this together has huge consequences for all of Denmark. Huge consequences. But the alternative - not to do anything - would be far worse. I hope that there will be an understanding of that. I am convinced that there will be. Normally, a government would not go out with such intrusive messages without having the solutions ready for all affected. But we are in a completely extraordinary situation. I would say honestly. It raises many and completely relevant questions. And neither myself nor the authorities all have the answers yet. I would also say honestly: We will not get through this at no cost. Businesses will experience loss. Some will lose their work. The government will do what we can to mitigate the consequences for both businesses and employees. We are in dialogue with the social partners on how to do it best. In addition, I would strongly encourage all vulnerable citizens to stay home. Staying home. Those that Corona can hit particularly hard. Everyone who is healthy has a huge responsibility for the most vulnerable. I hear in many places from the fact that many have already organized. Found solutions. For example, with the neighbor buying in. You cook for each other. You keep an eye out and pay attention. Now let's show what we can do when it comes to. The Danes are underway. We exhibit social minds. That's what works. Much of the solution to what we are facing, rests on the shoulders of the Danes. I would again like to say thank you for a good cooperation with the parties of the Folketing. Tonight I met with the party leaders and the parliamentary chairman on urgent legislation in a number of areas. There is full support for us to have the necessary tools ready in the Epidemic Act and other legislation. In the end, I can mention that I have gone through my calendar myself. I will not participate in outward activities for the next 14 days. The same goes for my ministers. When we hold meetings in the Prime Minister, we sit on every other chair. Like here for the press conference today. It might be small things. But it is also the sum of the little things that are part of the solution. I realize that what I, with the authorities, ask the Danes today are big things. Very intrusive. We do it because it has effect. We should not panic. We have to help each other. Show profits - think of others. Especially on those who are exposed. I would like to thank everyone in our healthcare system for the huge efforts you make. Thank you for your efforts now. And thanks in advance for your efforts in the coming days, weeks and months. I will say that as it is. It's going to be tough. The situation is going to make huge demands on all of us. But of course very special requirements for you who work in our hospitals. On the intensive care units. On the high -risk. We will very much need you in the very closest future. We stand on unprecedented land. We are in a situation that does not look like something we have tried before. Are we going to make mistakes? Yes. Are I going to make mistakes? Yes. I need your patience. We can't answer all questions right now. But on several, as soon as it can be done. Tomorrow there will be a press conference with the resource ministers. Here will also be the opportunity to ask questions. The announcement today will not be the last initiatives from the authorities. We all have to do everything we can to look after the Danes. In Denmark. On eachother.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale på Auschwitz-dagen
speeches_dk: Kære alle sammen.  I dag markerer vi noget, som aldrig burde være sket. I år er det 75 år siden, at anden verdenskrig sluttede. Vi markerer afslutningen på holocaust og nazisternes forbrydelser mod menneskeheden. I dag mindes vi ofrene. De ufatteligt mange. Som blev udsat for andre menneskers vanvid. Både i Auschwitz-Birkenau og ved andre folkedrab. Det hører historien til. Men det kommer nutiden ved. For fremtiden bygger på erfaringen.  Holocaust kostede omkring seks millioner jøder livet. Alene i Auschwitz-Birkenau døde mere end én million mennesker.  Auschwitz var et ophør af al menneskelighed. Al humanisme. Et ophør af den europæiske civilisation.  Det kan ikke forklares. Det kan ikke forsvares. Det kan ikke tilgives.  Jeg besøgte i fredags Yad Yashem. Anti-semitismen – som er det, holocaust handlede om – startede som satire og propaganda. Blev til ghettoer og jødestjerner. Så kom fattigdommen, dehumaniseringen og umyndiggørelsen. Volden og interneringen fulgte. Til sidst dødslejrene. Omfanget var og er så ubegribeligt, at vi stadig ikke helt kan forstå det. Halvanden million jødiske børn mistede livet dengang.  De som overlevede. I som overlevede. Var og er mærket hele livet. Mange forsøgte at glemme. Lægge rædslerne bag sig. For at kunne se frem. Leve videre.  Men som tiden gik, begyndte flere at fortælle.  I dag er der kun få tilbage, som selv oplevede rædslerne. Husker, hvad der skete.  Men vi som ikke var der. Vi må ikke glemme.  I Jerusalem i sidste uge mødte jeg to danske overlevere af holocaust. Jytte Israel og Robert Fischermann. Sikke et privilegium. Deres historie skal fortælles igen og igen – og leve videre. Jytte var en helt lille pige. Hun var en af de heldige europæiske jøder. Blev hjulpet både af folk, hun kendte. Og ukendte. Naboer og andre danskere der så det som deres opgave at hjælpe danske jøder godt på vej til Sverige. Hun blev fragtet afsted i fragtrummet af et stort kulskib. Godt hjulpet på vej af nogle snarrådige naboer på Islands Brygge. To unge tyske soldater som skulle til at inspicere skibet – blev i stedet narret væk med den sidste flaske franske cognac, man fandt i lejligheden. Roberts historie er helt anderledes og lidelsesfuld.  Familien – eller i hvert fald store dele af den – blev i 1943 fanget af tyskerne. Og Robert ender som kun 15-årig i Theresienstadt.  Robert fortæller mange ting, men især et par af dem vil jeg dele med jer. Fordi de selvfølgelig har gjort så stort indtryk. På den farlige rejse bliver Robert – sammen med nogle få familiemedlemmer – gennet ind i de kreaturvogne, som var en stor del af nazisternes infrastruktur i hele Europa. Stanken af alt for mange mennesker på alt for lidt plads. Sygdommen og desperationen. Tror jeg ikke nogen, der var der, nogensinde kommer til at lægge fra sig.  Robert fortæller om en ting, der måske er særlig vigtig. Nemlig de få gange, hvor kreaturvognene stopper undervejs. Og alle på brutal vis bliver gennet ud – for at forrette deres nødtørft.  Nogen vil sige – og hvad så? Men selv den ting var en fuldstændig bevidst handling fra nazisterne side. For der skulle man så sidde. Blottet. Med mennesker man ikke kendte. På kryds og tværs – af køn og alder og familiestand. Og det var faktisk dét, der var nazisterne ønske. At værdigheden, myndigheden og det enkelte individ skulle tages ud af hver eneste jøde. Robert siger også, at "mennesker kan vænne sig til mange ting. Men det man aldrig vænner sig til – det er sulten".  Både Robert og Jytte overlevede. Og de er her stadig. De lever ikke for evigt. Og det måske vigtigste vi kan love hinanden. Det er at lade beretningerne leve. For selvom jeg er et vedholdende optimistisk menneske. Så er noget af det, der kan bekymre mig – det er, når de sidste vidner ikke længere er iblandt os. Hvordan skal vi så sikre, at erindringen får lov at leve videre? Og det var jo ikke kun seks millioner jøder, der mistede livet under holocaust.  Det var også deres børn, deres børnebørn og deres oldebørn.  Med arrangementet i dag hjælper I os alle sammen med at holde erindringen i live.  Tak for det.  At huske og erindre er vigtigt. Men det kan ikke stå alene. Vi bliver nødt til at bruge den erindring til at gøre alt, hvad vi kan, for at historien aldrig gentager sig.  Derfor vil jeg gerne bruge den her aften. Til endnu engang. At udtrykke min dybeste foragt. Over for de mennesker, som også i vor tid – og i vort land – puster til antisemitismen.  De er her. De siger det. De gør det. Og vi må ikke – og vi skal ikke acceptere det. Trusler mod jøder og andre minoriteter i Danmark er en trussel mod os alle. Mod de værdier hvorpå vi har bygget et af verdens bedste samfund. De værdier som binder os sammen.  Friheden til at være den man er. Tro på den Gud man vil. I tryghed for sig selv og sine børn. Den er universel. Intet mindretal skal udsættes for had. Det er ikke det Danmark, vi ønsker.  I stedet for at dele os i grupper skal vi samles om at styrke fællesskabet. Engagere os i samfundet. På tværs af det, der kan skille os ad. Det har vi tradition for i Danmark.  Og det er måske også en af grundene til, at så mange danskere hjalp danske jøder med at overleve holocaust.  Man hjalp ikke en jøde. Man hjalp sin nabo. Et medmenneske. En dansker. En bekendt. En ven. Eller en helt ukendt. Fordi det var ens forpligtelse. Her viste det danske fællesskab sin styrke og vigtighed. Og det valg skal vi træffe igen. Lad os bruge historiens allermørkeste kapitler til i fællesskab at bekæmpe antisemitismen, racismen og det had, der desværre lever i dele af det danske samfund.  Og dermed i fællesskab stå fast – og stå op – for demokratiet, retsstaten og friheden.  For det er – når alt kommer til alt – det bedste værn og eneste værn, vi har imod umenneskelighed. I Danmark. Europa. Og resten af verden. Må vi aldrig glemme det, der skete.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech on Auschwitz Day
speeches_EN: Dear everyone. Today we mark something that should never have happened. This year is 75 years since World War II ended. We mark the end of the Holocaust and the Nazis' crimes against humanity. Today we remember the victims. The unimaginably many. Which was exposed to other people's madness. Both in Auschwitz-Birkenau and by other genocide. It belongs to the story. But the present comes to the present. For the future, the experience is based. The Holocaust cost about six million Jews life. In Auschwitz-Birkenau alone, more than one million people died. Auschwitz was a cessation of all humanity. All humanism. A cessation of European civilization. It cannot be explained. It cannot be defended. It cannot be forgiven. I visited last Friday's Yad Yashem. Anti-semitism-which is what Holocaust was about-started as satire and propaganda. Became ghettos and Jewish stars. Then came the poverty, dehumanization and the impairment. The violence and the internment followed. Eventually the death camps. The scope was and is so incomprehensible that we still can't quite understand it. One and a half million Jewish children lost their lives back then. Those who survived. You who survived. Was and is labeled all life. Many tried to forget. Put the horrors behind him. In order to look forward. Live on. But as time went on, several began to tell. Today, there are only a few left who even experienced the horrors. Remembering what happened. But we who were not there. We must not forget. In Jerusalem last week I met two Danish survivors of the Holocaust. Jytte Israel and Robert Fischermann. What a privilege. Their story must be told again and again - and live on. Jytte was a very little girl. She was one of the lucky European Jews. Was helped by both people she knew. And unknown. Neighbors and other Danes who saw it as their job to help Danish Jews well on their way to Sweden. She was shipped in the freight room by a large coal ship. Well helped along the way by some sneaky neighbors at Islands Brygge. Two young German soldiers who were going to inspect the ship - were instead fooled away with the last bottle of French cognac found in the apartment. Robert's story is completely different and suffering. The family - or at least large parts of it - was caught in 1943 by the Germans. And Robert ends up as a only 15-year-old in Theresienstadt. Robert tells many things, but especially a few of them I want to share with you. Because of course they have made such a big impression. On the dangerous journey, Robert - along with a few family members - is being re -entered into the creature wagons that were a major part of the Nazis' infrastructure throughout Europe. The stench of too many people in too little space. The disease and desperation. I don't think anyone who was there will ever put on. Robert tells of a thing that may be particularly important. Namely, the few times when the cattle trucks stop along the way. And everyone brutally is reinforced - to do their emergency needs. Someone will say - and what then? But even that thing was a completely conscious act of the Nazis. Because there you had to sit. Devoid of. With people you didn't know. Across - of gender and age and family level. And that was actually what the Nazis were wishing. That the dignity, the authority and the individual should be taken out of every Jew. Robert also says that "people can get used to many things. But what you never get used to - it's hungry". Both Robert and Jytte survived. And they are still here. They do not live forever. And perhaps the most important thing we can promise each other. It is to let the stories live. Because even though I am a persistent optimistic person. Then one of the things that can worry me - that's when the last witnesses are no longer among us. How should we make sure that the memory is allowed to live on? And it wasn't just six million Jews who lost their lives during the Holocaust. It was also their children, their grandchildren and their great -grandchildren. With the event today, you all help to keep the memory alive. Thank you. Remembering and remembering is important. But it can't stand alone. We need to use that memory to do everything we can to make the story never repeat. Therefore, I would like to use this evening. To once again. To express my deepest contempt. To the people who also breathe in our time - and in our country - to anti -Semitism. They are here. They say so. They do. And we must not - and we must not accept it. Threats to Jews and other minorities in Denmark are a threat to all of us. Against the values ​​on which we have built one of the world's best communities. The values ​​that bind us together. The freedom to be who you are. Believe in the God one wants. In security for himself and his children. It is universal. No minority should be exposed to hatred. That's not the Denmark we want. Instead of sharing us in groups, we need to gather to strengthen the community. Engage us in society. Across what can separate us. We have that tradition in Denmark. And this is perhaps one of the reasons why so many Danes helped Danish Jews survive the Holocaust. One did not help a Jew. You helped your neighbor. A fellow human being. A Dane. A known. A friend. Or a completely unknown. Because it was one's commitment. Here the Danish community showed its strength and importance. And we have to make that choice again. Let's use the very darkest chapters of history to jointly fight anti -Semitism, racism and the hatred that unfortunately live in parts of Danish society. And thus jointly standing firm - and standing up - for democracy, the rule of law and freedom. For it is - after all - the best protection and only protection we have against inhumanity. In Denmark. Europe. And the rest of the world. May we never forget what happened.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens tale ved genforeningsfejring
speeches_dk: Deres Majestæt. Deres kongelige højhed.  Kære gæster! For hundrede år siden blev Sønderjylland genforenet med Danmark. Nationen blev helet. Sønderjyderne kom hjem.  Ikke med vold og magt. Ikke med krige og konflikter, som gennem historien har kostet alt for mange mennesker livet. Revet familier i stykker. I både Danmark og Tyskland.  Nej. Denne gang fandt vores forfædre grænsen med en fredelig folkeafstemning. I respekt for de mennesker, som boede i regionen. I respekt for hinanden. Den måde at løse en grænsestrid på er helt unik. Jeg tror ikke, der er mange steder i verden – om nogen – hvor en grænse er tegnet så demokratisk.  Genforeningen er ikke alene en vigtig del af vores historie.  Den trækker tråde frem til vores egen tid.  Til hvem vi er i dag.  Vi er et land, som beslutter store ting i fællesskab. Lytter til hinanden. Og tager ansvar for fremtiden.  Vi gør det sammen. Også sammen med vore naboer. Ja, sammen med hele Europa.  Vi har modet. Til at se ud over vores eget land. Vor egen tid. Huske næste generation. Mod til at stille de store spørgsmål. Tage de rigtige beslutninger. I 1920 blev spørgsmålet til den enkelte sat på spidsen: Hvem er du?  Er du dansk? Eller er du tysk?  Og efter afstemningen var der stadig danskere på den tyske side. Og tyskere på den danske side. Dem må vi ikke glemme. Derfor er det så vigtigt, at landegrænsen ikke kun skiller. Men også samler. Og giver plads til, at man kan være – både dansk og tysk.  Danske skoler og tyske skoler, biblioteker og børnehaver ligger dør om dør i grænseregionen.  Det gør mig glad at tænke på.  Til mindretallene på begge sider af grænsen vil jeg sige: I kan i den grad være stolte.  Flertallet respekterer mindretallet. Og mindretallet respekterer flertallet.  I viser, at man både kan holde fast i sin egen kultur. Og respektere flertallets.  Man kan have hjertet med begge steder. I Danmark. Og i Tyskland.  I er en inspiration og et forbillede for hele verden.  Og et symbol på det nære og tillidsfulde forhold mellem Danmark og Tyskland. Derfor fejrer vi ikke alene en grænse, som blev trukket af folket. Vi fejrer også de broer, der bliver bygget mellem mennesker og lande – af folket.  For 100 år siden var genforeningen en begivenhed, der optog hele Danmark – ikke kun sønderjyderne.  100 år efter skal vi igen fejre genforeningen i hele Danmark. Vi kan endda samtidig fejre et fælles dansk-tysk kulturvenskabsår i 2020.  I aften skyder vi festlighederne i gang her på Det Kongelige Teater i København. Med en buket af kunstneriske indslag. Og en verdenspremiere på en tysk-dansk pas de deux. Skabt specielt til i aften. Men det er kun begyndelsen på en lang række begivenheder. Frem til den 11. juli, hvor der er fest på Dybbøl Banke.  Tak til alle jer, der har arbejdet hårdt med at få alting på plads. I har gjort det godt. Takket være jer er hele Danmark med, når vi markerer en vigtig del af vores fælles fortid. For 100 år siden lagde ansvarlige og fremsynede mennesker sporene for det fredelige grænsefællesskab, vi har i dag.  Lad os gå videre i deres fodspor. Mod en fælles fremtid båret af venskab, respekt og frihed. Med de ord. God fornøjelse med aftenens forestilling.  Og rigtig godt genforeningsår.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's speech by reunion celebration
speeches_EN: Your Majesty. Your Royal Highness. Dear guests! A hundred years ago, Southern Jutland was reunited with Denmark. The nation was healed. The Southern Jews came home. Not with violence and power. Not with wars and conflicts that have cost too many people throughout history. Torn families to pieces. In both Denmark and Germany. No. This time, our ancestors found the limit with a peaceful referendum. In respect of the people who lived in the region. In respect of each other. The way to solve a boundary battle is completely unique. I don't think there are many places in the world - about anyone - where a boundary is drawn so democratic. The reunion is not only an important part of our history. It pulls threads to our own time. To whom we are today. We are a country that decides big things together. Listening to each other. And takes responsibility for the future. We do it together. Also with our neighbors. Yes, along with all of Europe. We have the courage. To look out over our own country. Our own time. Remember the next generation. Courage to ask the big questions. Make the right decisions. In 1920, the question for the individual was at the forefront: Who are you? Are you Danish? Or are you German? And after the vote, there were still Danes on the German side. And Germans on the Danish side. We must not forget them. Therefore, it is so important that the border not only separates. But also collects. And gives room for one to be - both Danish and German. Danish schools and German schools, libraries and kindergartens are door to door in the border region. It makes me happy to think about. To the minorities on both sides of the border I would say: You can be proud to that extent. The majority respects the minority. And the minority respects the majority. You show that one can both hold on to your own culture. And respect the majority's. You can have the heart in both places. In Denmark. And in Germany. You are an inspiration and an example of the whole world. And a symbol of the close and trusting relationship between Denmark and Germany. Therefore, we are not only celebrating a border that was drawn by the people. We also celebrate the bridges that are built between people and countries - by the people. 100 years ago, the reunion was an event that recorded all of Denmark - not just the South Jews. 100 years later we will again celebrate the reunion throughout Denmark. We can even celebrate a common Danish-German cultural year in 2020. Tonight we are shooting the festivities here at the Royal Theater in Copenhagen. With a bouquet of artistic touches. And a world premiere of a German-Danish pas de Deux. Created specifically for tonight. But this is only the beginning of a host of events. Until July 11, where there is a party at Dybbøl Banke. Thank you to all of you who have worked hard to get everything in place. You have done well. Thanks to you, all of Denmark is involved when we mark an important part of our common past. 100 years ago, responsible and foresighted people made the traces of the peaceful boundary community we have today. Let's move on in their footsteps. Against a common future carried by friendship, respect and freedom. With those words. Good pleasure with tonight's performance. And really good reunification year.

topics_dk: Mette Frederiksens nytårstale
speeches_dk: Godaften. I år er det hundrede år siden, Sønderjylland blev genforenet med Danmark. Nationen blev helet. Sønderjyderne kom hjem. Det skal vi fejre.  Dengang – i efterveerne af Første Verdenskrig – stod vores forfædre over for et afgørende valg. Skulle folket følge landet? Eller skulle landet følge folket?  Danmark valgte det sidste. En folkeafstemning blev udskrevet. Danmark blev genforenet. På fredelig og demokratisk vis. Der er nu respekt og hjerterum for det tyske og danske mindretal på begge sider af grænsen.  Genforeningen i 1920 fortæller meget om os danskere.  Store beslutninger om vores samfund – og fremtid – træffer vi klogt. Med holdbare resultater. Og vi gør det fælles.  * * * I dag begynder vi på et nyt år. Vi tager også hul på et nyt årti. Nu skal vi i gang med at tage de næste store skridt. Og sammen skabe et Danmark, der er endnu mere retfærdigt.  Det handler om os alle sammen. Men det starter med vores børn.  Dem vil jeg gerne tale om i aften.  Her på årets første dag kommer lidt mere end 100 børn til verden – altså her i Danmark. Stort tillykke til alle de små. Og til alle jer forældre. Nogle af jer er nok allerede kommet hjem. Andre er stadig på fødestuen. Måske har jordemoderen eller SOSU-assistenten lige været forbi med et lille dannebrogsflag, et glas saftevand, en skive brød og lidt ost.  Det er en stor dag. Sjældent har et stykke ristet toastbrød smagt så godt som lige nu. Et nyt liv er begyndt.  Vores familiebaggrund betyder meget for vores liv og fremtid.  Når jeg skal forstå mine egne værdier, min måde at være mor på, mit forhold til religion og traditioner. Mine politiske holdninger. Ja, sågar mine madvaner – så er der ganske meget, der har rod i min opvækst hjemme i Aalborg.  Vi former vores børn. Det er en vigtig del af det at være familie. Sådan lever vores danske kultur videre fra én generation til den næste. Sammen har vi skabt et samfund. Bygget på tillid. Et velfærdssamfund. Hvor stadig flere har fået muligheder, som vores forældre ikke havde. Det kan vi godt være stolte af.  Stolte. Men ikke tilfredse. For selvom vi nu skriver år 2020. Og selvom langt de fleste nyfødte børn selvfølgelig kommer til at klare sig godt. Så gælder det ikke for dem alle. Der er et mønster. For hvor godt vi klarer os i skolen. Vores arbejdsliv. Ja endda, hvor gamle vi hver især kan forvente at blive.  Det er ikke retfærdigt. Jeg tror på et samfund, hvor det nytter at gøre en indsats. Ethvert menneske har grundlæggende ansvaret for sit eget liv.  Men vi kan ikke overlade hele ansvaret til den enkelte. Og da slet ikke til børn. Hvis børns opvækst bestemmer deres fremtid. Så er mønstret stadig for stærkt. Og fællesskabet for svagt. Et nyt årti. En ny generation bliver født og vokser op.  Vi skal fejre og hylde mønsterbryderne. Men vi skal først og fremmest stå sammen om at bryde mønstret.  * * * Vi har et særligt ansvar for de børn, der har det allersværest. Børn, der har oplevet misbrug, vold og svigt. I Danmark er der flere tusinde børn, som ikke kan bo hjemme hos deres egen mor og far. Fordi deres forældre ikke kan passe ordentligt på dem. For nogle uger siden havde jeg besøg af nogle af de børn her på Marienborg.  Vi spiste æbleskiver og klippede julepynt. Det blev også til en gåtur i haven. Børnene havde gnist i øjnene. Krudt i bagdelen.  Vi hyggede os.  Men vi snakkede også om ensomhed. Om mobning. Og om hvordan det er, når rollerne byttes rundt. Når børn bliver voksne før tid og skal passe på de mindre søskende. På tom mave – fordi køleskabet er tomt.  Andre udsatte børn har fortalt det samme. Om at føle sig tvunget til at skulle se de forældre, der har gjort én ondt. Og samtidig føle skyld over ikke at være hjemme. For hvem passer nu på far og mor?  Vi kan tale om det med en distance. Som gør, at det er til at holde ud – for os voksne.  Det vil jeg ikke gøre.  Jeg vil sige det, som det er. Uden omsvøb. Når samfundet reagerer for sent. Eller slet ikke reagerer. Når vi tager for mange hensyn til de voksne. Så betyder det, at der er børn i Danmark, som vokser op med omsorgssvigt og vold.  Det kan vi ikke forsvare. Det skal vi ikke forsvare. Og de børn, der allerede er anbragte. De fleste af dem fortæller, at de har det godt dér, hvor de bor nu. Men virkeligheden er også. At vi som samfund ikke altid er gode nok til at passe på dem.  Der kan være mange opbrud. Nye plejefamilier. Flere opholdssteder. Forskellige sagsbehandlere. Skoleskift. Ikke bare én gang. Ikke bare to gange. Men mange gange. Prøv at forestille dig, hvordan det må være. At pakke skoletasken. Møde op i en ny klasse. Igen. Forsøge at lære ansigter og navne at kende. Spekulere over, om man måske finder en ven? Og være bange for at om lidt. Så bliver man måske flyttet endnu en gang.  Det er en tung bagage på spinkle skuldre. For tung. Jeg har truffet et valg.  Jeg vil altid stå på børnenes side. Jeg håber, at I – der ser med – vil træffe det valg sammen med mig.  Det kommer med en pris. Det gør enhver svær beslutning.  Ligegyldigt hvor dårligt mennesker har det. Så vil vi alle sammen det bedste for vores børn.  Men i dag får nogle forældre for mange chancer. Måske i den bedste mening. Men når en 12-årig bliver fjernet fra hjemmet, så ligger der ofte 11 dårlige år bag.  Derfor må vi lægge berøringsangsten væk.  Også over for andre kulturer. Nogle forældre kommer fra lande, hvor vold mod børn er tilladt. Det er det ikke i Danmark. I Danmark er det forbudt at slå sine børn. Og piger skal have samme frihed som drenge.  Vi må træde i karakter som samfund. Flere udsatte børn skal have et nyt hjem. Tidligere end i dag. Og vilkårene for anbragte børn skal være langt mere stabile. Det vigtigste. Det helt afgørende for et lille barn. Det er at vokse op med tryghed, kærlighed og stabilitet. Derfor bør flere udsatte børn også bortadopteres. Så de får en reel ny start.  Jeg ved godt, at det ikke er alle, der vil være enige med mig. Nogle vil sige, at vi skal forebygge mere. Hjælpe familierne.  Det skal vi. Men det vil ikke være nok. Vi må entydigt tage børnenes parti.  Lytte til dem.  I november skrev seks unge en kronik om det at være anbragt. Jeg har mødt jer. I har sagt kloge ord. Om hvordan det er at møde voksne, der ikke har forventninger til jer. "Så har vi heller ikke forventninger til os selv". Sådan skrev I.  Jeres ord har gjort et stort indtryk på mig. Og fortæller, at der er noget, vi skal huske som samfund.  At forventninger faktisk er et udtryk for omsorg. At vi tager hinanden alvorligt.  Vi må ikke – i misforstået hensyn – møde andre uden krav.  Fremskridt kommer kun, hvis vi tror på hinanden. Hvis vi i fællesskab tør sætte nye mål. Og sammen arbejder for at nå dem. Det har vi før vist.  Danmark var det første land i verden, som besluttede, at alle børn skal have undervisning. Og vi var blandt de første lande til at afskaffe børnearbejde. Begge dele mødte modstand.  I 90'erne gik vi foran. Da vi gjorde det forbudt at slå børn. Ikke alle var enige. Også dengang mente nogen, at de voksnes ret kom først.  Nu skal vi skrive næste kapitel i børnenes Danmarkshistorie.  * * * Et mere retfærdigt samfund starter med børnene.  Men det slutter ikke her. Der er også uretfærdighed i den anden ende af livet. Når arbejdslivet slutter, og livets skjorte bliver for kort.  Tusindvis af danskere har hver eneste dag, år efter år, arbejdet for at forsørge sig selv og deres familier. Og for at vi kan tilbyde børn og unge gratis skolegang og uddannelse. Hver generation arver Danmark fra den forrige.  Det skylder vi vores ældre tak for. Og vi skylder at gøre det bedre. I vores ældrepleje. Og i tiden inden man kan gå på pension. For nogle har knoklet så meget. At kroppen ikke kan blive ved.  Det er ikke retfærdigt, at I, der har haft det hårdeste arbejde. Eller været flest år på arbejdsmarkedet. Skal opleve. At velfærdssamfundet ikke er der for jer, når I har brug for det.  Hvis vi skal gøre op med den uretfærdighed. Indføre en ny ret til tidligere pension. Så bliver der brug for solidaritet.  Særligt fra alle os, der har haft mulighederne for at tage en længere uddannelse og er startet senere på arbejdsmarkedet.  * * * At være forpligtet over for hinanden er det stærkeste bånd mellem os mennesker. Vi har brug for, at alle føler ansvar over for det land, vi lever i.  Desværre ser vi for mange eksempler på det modsatte.  Svindel med offentlige midler. Det er uacceptabelt. Et tillidsbrud. I året, der gik, tog vanvidskørsel livet fra en ung betjent. Eksplosioner rystede København. Fremmedkrigere. Bandeopgør. Fyrværkeri brugt som chikane. For få uger siden viste politiet igen sit værd. Flere blev anholdt. Mistænkt for at planlægge terror.  Vores myndigheder skal have de bedste redskaber. Derfor skal vi sætte hårdt ind mod bandekriminalitet. Skærpe straffen for vanvidskørsel i gaderne. Og give strengere straffe til de fremmedkrigere, der har vendt Danmark ryggen.  Vi skal være årvågne. Beskytte vores tryghed. Og dermed vores frihed. * * * Dengang for 100 år siden, da sønderjyderne kom hjem til Danmark. Da stod valget mellem, om folket skulle følge landet. Eller om landet skulle følge folket.  Vi valgte det sidste.  Sådan er det også i klimakampen.  I aften har jeg talt om de børn, der har det sværest. Men i de her år viser danske børn og unge også, at de aldrig har været stærkere.  I gik på gaden. I krævede handling. I har skubbet til jeres forældre og bedsteforældre. I gjorde Folketingsvalget sidste år til et klimavalg. Det er stærkt. I giver håb. Hold fast i jeres engagement. Og bliv ved med at presse os voksne. Klimaet handler om jer og jeres fremtid.  Takket være jer har vi nu den mest ambitiøse klimalov i Danmark. Nogensinde.  Nu ser resten af verden igen i Danmarks retning.  Mere urørt skov, mere vedvarende energi. Flere forskningsmidler til fremtidens løsninger. Og en styrket grøn indsats i verden.  Vores udledning af drivhusgasser skal ned og vores natur skal have det bedre. Det kræver noget af os alle sammen. Vi ser ind i store forandringer i den måde, vi lever og producerer på. Vi skal træffe beslutningerne klogt. Så de også gavner dansk erhvervsliv, beskæftigelsen og dansk økonomi. Og uden at uligheden stiger.  Men handle – det skal vi. Det skylder vi den jordklode, vi kun har til låns. * * * Jeg tror på Danmark. På vores samfundsmodel. Vores fælles stræben efter at skabe et stadig mere retfærdigt samfund.  Hvor vi igen styrker tilliden som vores fælles fundament.  Jeg tror på os.  Hvis vi vil. Så kan vi være et land, hvor ingen overlades til sig selv. Et samfund, hvor vi tager os af hinanden.  Et nyt år. Et nyt årti. Lad os bruge det. Til at huske dem, som ellers bliver glemt.  Godt nytår.
topics_EN: Mette Frederiksen's New Year's speech
speeches_EN: Good evening. This year it is a hundred years since Southern Jutland was reunited with Denmark. The nation was healed. The Southern Jews came home. We must celebrate that. Back then - in the aftermath of World War I - our ancestors faced a crucial choice. Should the people follow the country? Or should the country follow the people? Denmark chose the latter. A referendum was discharged. Denmark was reunited. Peaceful and democratic way. There is now respect and heart room for the German and Danish minorities on both sides of the border. The reunion in 1920 tells a lot about us Danes. Great decisions about our society - and future - we make wisely. With durable results. And we do it in common. * * * Today we start in a new year. We are also embarking on a new decade. Now we have to start taking the next big steps. And together create a Denmark that is even fairer. It's about all of us. But it starts with our children. I would like to talk about them tonight. Here on the first day of the year, a little more than 100 children come to the world - ie here in Denmark. Big congratulations to all the little ones. And to all of you parents. Some of you have probably already come home. Others are still at the birthplace. Maybe the midwife or the SOSU assistant has just been over with a small formation bridge flag, a glass of juice, a slice of bread and some cheese. It's a great day. Rarely has a piece of toasted toast bread tasted as good as right now. A new life has begun. Our family background means a lot to our lives and future. When I need to understand my own values, my way of being a mother, my relationship with religion and traditions. My political attitudes. Yes, even my eating habits - there is quite a lot that is rooted in my upbringing at home in Aalborg. We shape our children. It is an important part of being family. This is how our Danish culture lives on from one generation to the next. Together we have created a society. Built on trust. A welfare society. Where more and more people have been given opportunities that our parents did not have. We may well be proud of that. Proud. But not satisfied. Because even though we are now writing the year 2020. And although the vast majority of newborn children will of course do well. Then it does not apply to all of them. There is a pattern. For how well we are doing in school. Our working life. Yes even how old we can each expect to stay. That's not fair. I believe in a society where it is useful to make an effort. Every human being has basic responsibility for his or her own life. But we cannot leave the whole responsibility to the individual. And then not at all for children. If children's upbringing determines their future. Then the pattern is still too strong. And the community too weak. A new decade. A new generation is born and growing up. We need to celebrate and pay tribute to the pattern breakers. But we must first and foremost stand together to break the pattern. * * * We have a special responsibility for the children who have the worst. Children who have experienced abuse, violence and failure. In Denmark, there are several thousand children who cannot live with their own mother and father. Because their parents can't fit them properly. A few weeks ago I had a visit from some of the children here at Marienborg. We ate apple slices and cut Christmas decorations. It also turned into a walk in the garden. The children had sparkle in their eyes. Powder in the back. We had a great time. But we also talked about loneliness. About bullying. And about what it is like when the roles are swapped around. When children become adults ahead of time and have to look after the smaller siblings. On an empty stomach - because the refrigerator is empty. Other vulnerable children have told the same. About feeling compelled to see the parents who have hurt one. And at the same time feel guilty about not being at home. Who now looks after dad and mom? We can talk about it with a distance. Which makes it to be to endure - for us adults. I won't do that. I will say that as it is. Without bullshit. When society responds too late. Or not responding at all. When we take too many into account of the adults. Then this means that there are children in Denmark who grow up with neglect and violence. We can't defend that. We should not defend that. And the children who are already placed. Most of them say they are doing well where they live now. But the reality is too. That we as a society are not always good enough to look after them. There can be many break -ups. New foster families. More places of residence. Different caseworkers. School change. Not just once. Not just twice. But many times. Try to imagine what it must be like. To pack the school bag. Meeting up in a new class. Again. Try to get to know faces and names. Wonder if you might find a friend? And be afraid of in a little while. Then you might be moved again. It's a heavy luggage on flimsy shoulders. Too heavy. I have made a choice. I will always stand on the children's side. I hope you - who watch - will make that choice with me. It comes with a price. It makes every difficult decision. No matter how bad people have it. Then we all want the best for our children. But today some parents get too many chances. Maybe in the best sense. But when a 12-year-old is removed from home, there are often 11 bad years behind. Therefore, we must put away the touch of touch. Also to other cultures. Some parents come from countries where violence against children is allowed. It is not in Denmark. In Denmark it is forbidden to beat his children. And girls must have the same freedom as boys. We must take on character as a society. Several vulnerable children need a new home. Earlier than today. And the conditions for placed children must be far more stable. The most important. The crucial thing for a small child. It is to grow up with security, love and stability. Therefore, more vulnerable children should also be adopted. So they get a real new start. I know well that not everyone will agree with me. Some would say we need to prevent more. Help the families. We should. But that won't be enough. We must unequivocally take the children's party. Listen to them. In November, six young people wrote a chronicle about being placed. I've met you. You have said wise words. About what it is like to meet adults who do not have expectations for you. "Then we don't have expectations of ourselves either". This is how I wrote your words made a big impression on me. And tells you that there is something we need to remember as a society. That expectations are actually an expression of care. That we take each other seriously. We must not - in misunderstood consideration - meet others without requirements. Progress only comes if we believe each other. If we jointly dare set new goals. And together working to reach them. We have shown that before. Denmark was the first country in the world to decide that all children should be taught. And we were among the first countries to abolish child labor. Both of them met resistance. In the 90s we went ahead. When we did it forbidden to beat children. Not everyone agreed. Even then, someone thought the right of adults came first. Now we have to write the next chapter in the children's Danish history. * * * A more just society starts with the children. But it doesn't end here. There is also injustice at the other end of life. When working life ends and the shirt of life becomes too short. Thousands of Danes have worked every single day, year after year, to support themselves and their families. And so that we can offer children and young people free schooling and education. Each generation inherits Denmark from the previous one. We owe our older thanks for that. And we owe to doing better. In our elderly care. And in the time before you can retire. For some, the knuckle has so much. That the body cannot stay on. It is not fair that you have had the hardest work. Or been the most years in the labor market. Must experience. That the welfare society is not there for you when you need it. If we are to do away with that injustice. Introduce a new right to previous pension. Then solidarity will be needed. Especially from all of us who have had the opportunities to take a longer education and have started later in the labor market. * * * Being obliged to each other is the strongest bond between us humans. We need everyone to feel responsible for the country we live in. Unfortunately, we see too many examples of the opposite. Fraud with public funds. It's unacceptable. A breach of trust. In the year that passed, madness driving took the life of a young officer. Explosions shook Copenhagen. Foreign warriors. Gang settlement. Fireworks used as harassment. A few weeks ago, police again showed their worth. Several were arrested. Suspected of planning terror. Our authorities must have the best tools. Therefore, we need to go hard against gang crime. Sharpen the penalty for madness driving in the streets. And give stricter penalties to the foreign warriors who have turned Denmark back. We have to be vigilant. Protect our security. And thus our freedom. * * * Back then 100 years ago when the South Jews came home to Denmark. Then the choice was whether the people should follow the country. Or whether the country should follow the people. We chose the last one. This is also the case in the climate fight. Tonight I have talked about the children who have the most difficulty. But in these years, Danish children and young people also show that they have never been stronger. You walked on the street. In required action. You have pushed to your parents and grandparents. You made the parliamentary election last year for a climate election. It is strong. I give hope. Hold on to your commitment. And keep pushing us adults. The climate is about you and your future. Thanks to you, we now have the most ambitious climate law in Denmark. Ever. Now the rest of the world is looking again in Denmark's direction. More untouched forest, more renewable energy. More research funding for future solutions. And a strengthened green effort in the world. Our greenhouse gas emissions need to go down and our nature must feel better. It requires something of us all. We look into major changes in the way we live and produce. We have to make the decisions wisely. So they also benefit Danish business, employment and the Danish economy. And without inequality rising. But act - we should. We owe it to the globe we only have on loan. * * * I believe in Denmark. On our social model. Our common pursuit of creating an ever -fair society. Where we again strengthen confidence as our common foundation. I believe in us. If we will. Then we can be a country where no one is left to himself. A society where we take care of each other. A new year. A new decade. Let's use it. To remember those who are otherwise forgotten. Happy New Year.
